A pool is a much smaller area of water When the tide went out, pools of water were left among the rocks.An artificial pool, however, can be larger a swimming pool. A puddle is a small pool of water made by the rain. lake（湖）的面积通常大得足以划船：Lake Como科莫湖。pond可能只足够供动物饮水，或指花园中的小水池：We have a fish pond in our garden.我们的花园里有一个鱼池。pool是范围更小的水洼：When the tide went out, pools of water were left among the rocks.退潮以后，岩石之间留下一滩滩水洼。然而，人造水池可能大一些：a swimming pool游泳池。雨后的小水坑叫做puddle。

ponder
/ˈpɒndə(r) ||; ˈpɑndɚ/verb [I,T] ponder (on/over sth) to think about sth carefully or for a long time 仔细考虑；深思: The teacher gave us a question to ponder over before the next class. 下一次上课以前，老师让我们思考一个问题。

ponderous
/pɒndərəs ||; ˈpɑndərəs/adj (written 书面语)
1 (used about speech and writing) too slow and careful; serious and boring ﹙言语或文字﹚慢条斯理的， 沉闷乏味的: He spoke in a slow ponderous voice. 他慢条斯理地开口说话。
2 moving slowly and heavily; able to move only slowly 缓慢的；笨拙的；笨重的: She watched the cow's ponderous progress. 她看着牛迟缓地向前走着。
➔ponderously adv

pong
/pɒŋ ||; pɔŋ/noun [C] (Brit 英) (slang 俚语) a strong unpleasant smell 浓烈的臭气；难闻的气味 pong verb [I]

pony
/ˈpəʊni ||; ˈponɪ/noun [C] (plural ponies) a small horse 小型马；矮种马

ponytail
/ˈpəʊniteɪl ||; ˈponɪˌtel/noun [C] long hair that is tied at the back of the head and that hangs down in one piece 马尾辫 ☞picture at hair 见hair插图

ˈpony-trekking
(US 美 trail riding) noun [U] the activity of riding horses for pleasure in the country 骑马郊游

pooch
/pu:tʃ ||; putʃ/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a dog 狗

poodle
/ˈpu:dl ||; ˈpudḷ/noun [C] a type of dog with thick curly fur that is sometimes cut into a special pattern 鬈毛狗；贵宾狗

pooh
/pu: ||; pu/ exclamation (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) said when you smell sth unpleasant （表示嗅到难闻气味时发出的嫌恶声）啐，呸

*pool¹
/pu:l ||; pul/noun
1 [C] a pool (of sth) a small amount of liquid lying on a surface 小池；水洼；水坑: There's a huge pool of water on the kitchen floor. 厨房地板上有一大汪水。 ☞Look at the note at pond. 参看pond的注释。
2 [C] a small area of light 一小片（光）: a pool of light 一小片光
3 [C] =SWIMMING POOL He swam ten lengths of the pool. 他在游泳池里游了五个来回。
4 [C] a quantity of money, goods, etc that is shared between a group of people 共享基金；共享物: There is a pool of cars that anyone in the company can use. 有一批公用汽车，任何公司员工都可以使用。
5 [U] a game that is played on a table with 16 coloured and numbered balls. Two players try to hit these balls into holes in the table (pockets) with long thin sticks (cues). 落袋台球游戏（一种室内游戏，桌上有16个有数字的颜色球。两个人每人要用球杆把球击入桌边洞内的袋中） ☞Look at billiards and snooker. 参看billiards及snooker。 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图
6 the pools [pl] =FOOTBALL POOLS
pool²
/pu:l ||; pul/verb [T] to collect money, ideas, etc together from a number of people （向若干人）收集（金钱、意见等）然后分享: If we pool our ideas we should come up with a good plan. 大家如果一起来凑主意，一定能想出个好办法。

pooper scooper
/pu:pə sku:pə(r) ||; ˈpupɚ ˌskupɚ/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a tool used by dog owners for removing their dogs' solid waste from the streets 狗粪铲

*poor
/pɔ:(r); US pʊər ||; pυr/adj
1 not having enough money to have a comfortable life 贫穷的；贫困的: The family was too poor to buy new clothes. 这一家穷得连新衣服也买不起。 Richer countries could do more to help poorer countries. 比较富裕的国家可以更多地帮助比较贫穷的国家。 [OPP] rich 反义词为rich
2 the poor noun [pl] people who do not have enough money to have a comfortable life 穷人；贫民
3 of low quality or in a bad condition 质劣的；情况差的: Paul is in very poor health. 保罗身体很差。 The industry has a poor safety record. 这行业的安全纪录很差。
4 used when you are showing that you feel sorry for sb （用于表示对某人感到难过）可怜，不幸: Poor Dan! He's very upset! 唐纳德真可怜！他苦恼极了！

poorly¹
/ˈpɔ:li; US ˈpʊərlɪ ||; ˈpυrlɪ/adv not well; badly 拙劣；不足: a poorly paid job 待遇很差的工作
poorly²
/ˈpɔ:li ||; ˈpυrlɪ/adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) not well; ill 身体不适；健康欠佳；有病的: I'm feeling a bit poorly. 我感到有点不舒服。
*pop²
/pɒp ||; pɑp/noun
1 [U] (also pop music) modern music that is most popular among young people 流行音乐: a pop group 流行乐队 ☞Look at jazz, rock and classical. 参看jazz、rock及classical。
2 [C] a short sudden sound like a small explosion 短促的爆裂声；砰（的一声）；啪（的一声）: There was a loud pop as the champagne cork came out of the bottle. 香槟酒瓶塞打开时，响亮地发出啪的一声。

pop¹
/pɒp ||; pɑp/verb (popping;popped)
1 [I,T] to make a short sudden sound like a small explosion; to cause sth to do this （使）发出短促的爆裂声: The balloon popped. 那气球啪的一声爆了。 He popped the balloon. 他啪的一声把气球弄破了。
2 [I] pop across, down, out, etc to come or go somewhere quickly or suddenly （迅速或突然）来，去: I'm just popping out to the shops. 我正赶到商店去。
3 [T] pop sth in, into, etc sth to put or take sth somewhere quickly or suddenly （迅速或突然）放进: She popped the note into her bag. 她迅速将字条放进包里。
pop in to make a quick visit 匆匆探访: Why don't you pop in for a cup of tea? 你怎么不进来喝杯茶？ pop out to come out (of sth) suddenly or quickly 突然或迅速地蹦出: Her eyes nearly popped out of her head in surprise. 她惊讶得眼珠子差点蹦出来。 pop up(informal 非正式) to appear or happen when you are not expecting it （出其不意地）出现，发生

pop.
abbr population 人口: pop. 12m 1200万人口

popcorn
/ˈpɒpkɔ:n ||; ˈpɑpˌkɔrn/noun [U] a type of corn that is heated until it bursts and forms light whitish balls that are eaten with salt or sugar on them 爆玉米花

ˌpop ˈculture
noun [U] commercial art, music, literature, etc which is enjoyed by a lot of ordinary people 流行文化

*pope
/pəʊp ||; pop/noun [C] the head of the Roman Catholic Church （天主教）教宗，教皇

poplar
/ˈpɒplə(r) ||; ˈpɑplɚ/noun [C] a tall straight tree with soft wood 杨树

popper
/ˈpɒpə(r) ||; ˈpɑpɚ/ (also ˈpress stud (US 美) snap) noun [C] two round pieces of metal or plastic that you press together in order to fasten a piece of clothing （衣服的）按扣，揿扣，子母扣 ☞picture at button 见button插图

poppy
/ˈpɒpi ||; ˈpɑpɪ/noun [C] (plural poppies) a bright red wild flower that has small black seeds 罂粟 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图

Popsicle™
/ˈpɒpsɪkl ||; ˈpɑpsɪkḷ/noun [C] (US 美) =ICE LOLLY

populace
/pɒpjələs ||; ˈpɑpjələs/noun [sing] (usually 通常作 the populace) (formal 正式) all the ordinary people of a particular country or area 平民百姓；民众: He had the support of large sections of the local populace. 他受到当地大部份民众的拥护。 The populace at large is/are opposed to sudden change. 民众普遍反对突然的改变。

*popular
/ˈpɒpjələ(r) ||; ˈpɑpjəlɚ/adj
1 popular (with sb) liked by many people or by most people in a group 流行的；风行的: a popular holiday resort 热门度假胜地 He's always been very popular with his pupils. 他一向深受学生爱戴。 [OPP] unpopular 反义词为unpopular
2 made for the tastes and knowledge of ordinary people 大众化的；通俗的: The popular newspapers seem more interested in scandal than news. 那些通俗报章似乎对丑闻的兴趣甚于新闻。
3 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) of or for a lot of people 大多数人的；为大多数人而设的: The programme is being repeated by popular demand. 这个节目应大众要求正在回放。

popularity
/ˌpɒpjuˈlærəti ||; ˌpɑpjəˈlærətɪ/noun [U] the quality or state of being liked by many people 讨人喜欢的特点；普及；流行；声望: The band's popularity is growing. 这个乐队的声望与日俱增。

popularize
/ˈpɒpjʊləraɪz ||; ˈpɑpjələˌraɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to make a lot of or most people like sth 使普及；推广；宣传: The film did a lot to popularize her novels. 这部电影大大推广了她的小说。

popularly
/ˈpɒpjələli ||; ˈpɑpjəlɚlɪ/adv by many people; generally 由大众或很多人；普遍；一般: The Conservatives are popularly known as the Tories. 保守党一般称为托利党。

populate
/ˈpɒpjuleɪt ||; ˈpɑpjəˌlet/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to fill a particular area with people （人）居住于，生活于（某地）: Parts of the country are very thinly populated. 该国有些地区人口十分稀少。

*population
/ˌpɒpjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌpɑpjəˈleʃən/noun
1 [C,U] the number of people who live in a particular area, city or country （某地方的）人口，居民人数: What is the population of your country? 你们国家有多少人口？ an increase/a fall in population 人口的增加╱减少
2 [C] all the people who live in a particular place or all the people or animals of a particular type that live somewhere （居住在某地的）全部人或动物: the local population 当地居民 the male/female population 男性╱女性居民 The prison population has increased in recent years. 最近几年监狱犯人增加了。

ˈpop-up
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used about a computer menu, etc) that can be brought to the screen quickly while you are working on another document ﹙计算机菜单等﹚有弹出功能的: a pop-up ad/menu/window 弹出式广告/菜单/窗口

porcelain
/ˈpɔ:səlɪn ||; ˈpɔrsḷɪn/noun [U] a hard white substance that is used for making expensive cups, plates, etc 瓷；瓷器

porch
/pɔ:tʃ ||; pɔrtʃ/noun[C]
1 (Brit 英) a small covered area at the entrance to a house or church （房子或教堂的）门廊，入口处
2 (US 美) =VERANDA

porcupine
/ˈpɔ:kjupaɪn ||; ˈpɔrkjəˌpaɪn/noun [C] an animal covered with long thin sharp parts(quills)which it can lift up to protect itself when it is attacked 豪猪（浑身长满尖刺，受到攻击时用以保护自己）

pore¹
/pɔ:(r) ||; pɔr/noun [C] one of the small holes in your skin through which sweat can pass （皮肤上让汗水排出的）毛孔，气孔
pore²
/pɔ:(r) ||; pɔr/verb pore over sth to study or read sth very carefully 钻研；专心阅读；研习

pork
/pɔ:k ||; pɔrk/noun [U] meat from a pig 猪肉 ☞Look at bacon and ham and at the note at meat. 参看bacon、ham及meat的注释。

porky
/pɔ:ki ||; ˈpɔrkɪ/adj (porkier; porkiest) (informal 非正式) (used about people) fat ﹙人﹚肥胖的

pornography
/pɔ:ˈnɒgrəfi ||; pɔrˈnɑgrəfɪ/ (informal 非正式porn /pɔ:n ||; pɔrn/) noun [U] books, magazines, films, etc that describe or show sexual acts in order to cause sexual excitement 色情作品（如色情书刊、电影等） ➔pornographic /ˌpɔ:nəˈgræfɪk ||; ˌpɔrnəˈgræfɪk/ adj

porous
/ˈpɔ:rəs ||; ˈpɔrəs/adj allowing liquid or air to pass through slowly 渗水的；漏气的: porous rock 渗水的岩石 [OPP] non-porous 反义词为non-porous

porpoise
/ˈpɔ:pəs ||; ˈpɔrpəs/noun [C] a sea animal with a pointed nose that lives in groups. Porpoises are similar to DOLPHINS but smaller 鼠海豚（一种海中动物，与海豚十分相似，成群生活）

porridge
/ˈpɒrɪdʒ; US ˈpɔ:r- ||; ˈpɔrɪdʒ/noun [U] a soft, thick white food that is made from a type of grain (oats) boiled with milk or water and eaten hot 粥，糊（用燕麦混和牛奶或水煮成）；麦片粥

*port
/pɔ:t ||; pɔrt/noun
1 [C,U] an area where ships stop to let goods and passengers on and off 港；港口: a fishing port 渔港 The damaged ship reached port safely. 那艘受损的船安全地抵达了港口。
2 [C] a town or city that has a large area of water where ships load cargo, etc 港市；口岸；港埠: Hamburg is a major port. 汉堡是个重要的港市。
3 [U] a strong sweet red wine 波尔图葡萄酒（一种性醇味甜的红酒）
4 [U] the side of a ship that is on your left when you are facing towards the front of the ship （船舶的）左舷，左边 [OPP] starboard 反义词为starboard

portable
/ˈpɔ:təbl ||; ˈpɔrtəbḷ/adj that can be moved or carried easily 便于携带的；手提式的: a portable television 手提电视机 ☞Look at movable and mobile. 参看movable及mobile。

portal
/ˈpɔ:tl ||; ˈpɔrtḷ/noun [C] a WEB SITE that is used as a point of entry to the Internet, where information has been collected that will be useful to a person interested in particular kinds of things （与因特网联网的）门户网站，门户站点: a business/health/children's portal 商业╱保健╱儿童门户网站

ˌportal ˈvein
(also heˌpatic ˌportal ˈvein) noun [C] (medical医学) a vein that takes blood from the stomach and other organs near the stomach to the LIVER(= the large organ in your body that cleans your blood) 门静脉

porter
/ˈpɔ:tə(r) ||; ˈpɔrtɚ/noun[C]
1 a person whose job is to carry suitcases, etc at a railway station, airport, etc （火车站、机场等的）搬运工人，行李工，脚夫
2 a person whose job is to be in charge of the entrance of a hotel or other large building （旅馆或其他大型建筑物的）看门人，门房

porthole
/ˈpɔ:thəʊl ||; ˈpɔrtˌhol/noun [C] a small round window in a ship （船的）舷窗

portion
/ˈpɔ:ʃn ||; ˈpɔrʃən/noun [C] a portion (of sth)
1 a part or share of sth （某物的）一部份，一份: What portion of your salary goes on tax? 你薪金中有多少用来付税款呢？ We must both accept a portion of the blame. 我们两人都必须负部份责任。
2 an amount of food for one person (especially in a restaurant) （食物的）一份，一客（尤指在餐馆里）: Could we have two extra portions of chips, please? 麻烦你，我们想多要两份炸马铃薯条。 ☞Look at helping. 参看helping。

portrait
/ˈpɔ:treɪt ||; ˈpɔrtret/noun[C]
1 a picture, painting or photograph of a person （一个人的）肖像，画像，照片: to paint sb's portrait 给某人画肖像
2 a description of sb/sth in words （文字）描述，描写

portray
/pɔ:ˈtreɪ ||; pɔrˈtre/verb[T]
1 to show sb/sth in a picture; to describe sb/sth in a piece of writing 用图画表现；用文字描述；描绘；刻划: Zola portrayed life in 19th-century France. 佐拉描述了19世纪法国的生活。
2 portray sb/sth as sth to describe sb/sth in a particular way 以某种方式描写: In many of his novels life is portrayed as being hard. 他的很多小说都把人生描绘成很艰辛的。
3 to act the part of sb in a play or film （在戏剧或电影中）扮演，饰演: In this film she portrays a very old woman. 她在这部电影中扮演一个老太太。 ➔portrayal /pɔ:ˈtreɪəl ||; pɔrˈtreəl/ noun [C]

pose¹
/pəʊz ||; poz/verb
1 [T] to create or give sb sth that he/she has to deal with 引起；造成；提出: to pose a problem/threat/challenge/risk 造成问题；造成威胁；提出挑战；构成风险 to pose (= ask) a question 提出一个问题
2 [I] to sit or stand in a particular position for a painting, photograph, etc （为绘画、拍照等）摆姿势: After the wedding we all posed for photographs. 婚礼后，我们所有人都摆好姿势拍照。
3 [I] pose as sb/sth to pretend to be sb/sth 假扮；乔装；冒充: The robbers got into the house by posing as telephone engineers. 那些劫匪假扮电话工程人员进入房子。
4 [I] to behave in a way that is intended to impress people who see you 装模作样，矫揉做作（藉以给人好印象）: They hardly swam at all. They just sat posing at the side of the pool. 他们根本没有游泳，只是装模作样坐在游泳池旁边。
pose²
/pəʊz ||; poz/noun[C]
1 a position in which sb stands, sits, etc especially in order to be painted or photographed 摆好姿势（尤指为了让人绘画或拍照）
2 a way of behaving that is intended to impress people who see you 装模作样

posh
/pɒʃ ||; pɑʃ/adj (informal 非正式)
1 fashionable and expensive 时髦而昂贵的；豪华的: We went for a meal in a really posh hotel. 我们到一家极豪华的旅馆吃饭。
2 (Brit 英) (used about people) belonging to or typical of a high social class （指人）上流社会的

*position¹
/pəˈzɪʃn ||; pəˈzɪʃən/noun
1 [C,U] the place where sb/sth is or should be （某人或某物所在或应在的）位置: Are you happy with the position of the chairs? 你对这些椅子的位置满意吗？ All the dancers were in position waiting for the music to begin. 所有舞蹈演员已经各就各位，等候音乐开始。
2 [C,U] the way in which sb/sth sits or stands, or the direction that sth is pointing in （某人的）姿势；（某物的）摆放方式或方向: My leg hurts when I change position. 我换姿势时觉得腿痛。 Turn the switch to the off position. 把开关转到关的位置。
3 [C] [usu.sing] the state or situation that sb/sth is in 处境；状况: I'm in a very difficult position. 我的处境很为难。 I'm sorry, I'm not in a position to help you financially. 抱歉，金钱方面我无能为力，帮不了你。
4 [C] a position (on sth) what you think about sth; your opinion （对某事的）态度，立场，意见: What is your position on smoking? 你对吸烟持什么态度？
5 [C,U] the place or level of a person, company, team, etc compared to others 地位；等级: the position of women in society 妇女的社会地位 Max finished the race in second position. 马克斯在那场赛跑中取得第二名。 Wealth and position are very important to some people. 财富和地位对有些人来说十分重要。
6 [C] a job 职位: There have been over a hundred applications for the position of Sales Manager. 已经收到一百多封申请销售经理职位的应征信。 [SYN] post 同义词为post
7 [C] the part you play in a team game （球队中的）位置: Danny can play any position except goalkeeper. 丹尼能踢任何位置，除了当守门员以外。
position²
/pəˈzɪʃn ||; pəˈzɪʃən/verb [T] to put sb/sth in a particular place or position 把（某人╱某物）安置在（某地方╱某位置）: Mary positioned herself near the door so she could get out quickly. 玛丽站近门口，那样她可以很快出来。

*positive
/ˈpɒzətɪv ||; ˈpɑzətɪv/adj
1 thinking or talking mainly about the good things in a situation, in a way that makes you or sb else feel hopeful and confident 积极的；正面的；肯定的: Their reaction to my idea was generally positive. 他们对我那个意见的反应大致是肯定的。 I feel very positiveabout our team's chances this season. 我非常相信这个赛季我们球队很有希望取胜。 Positive thinking will help you to succeed. 积极的思维能助你成功。 [OPP] negative 反义词为negative
2 positive (about sth/that...) certain; sure （对…）确定，有把握: Are you positive that this is the woman you saw? 你肯定这就是你见过的那个妇人吗？
3 clear; definite 明确的；清楚的；确切的: There is no positive evidence that he is guilty. 没有确实证据证明他有罪。 to take positive action 采取明确的行动
4 (used about a medical or scientific test) showing that sth has happened or is present （指医学或科学检验）阳性的（显示某事物已发生或存在）: The result of the pregnancy test was positive. 妊娠检验结果呈阳性。 Two athletes tested positive for steroids. 有两名运动员在类固醇检测中呈阳性。 [OPP] negative 反义词为negative
5 (used about a number) more than zero （指数字）正的 [OPP] negative 反义词为negative

positively
/ˈpɒzətɪvli ||; ˈpɑzətɪvlɪ/adv
1 with no doubt; firmly 肯定；坚决: I was positively convinced that I was doing the right thing. 我确信自己做得对。
2 in a way that shows you are thinking about the good things in a situation, not the bad 积极；往好的方面看: Thinking positively helps many people deal with stress. 以积极的角度思考有助于许多人应付精神压力。
3 (used about a person's way of speaking or acting) in a confident and hopeful way （指人的说话或行动方式）充满希望，有信心: The team played cautiously for the first ten minutes, then continued more positively. 该球队在前十分钟踢得谨慎，接下来就踢得比较有信心了。
4 (informal 非正式) (used for emphasizing sth) really; extremely （用于强调）很，极: He wasn't just annoyed -- he was positively furious! 他不仅生气而已─他暴跳如雷！

*possess
/pəˈzes ||; pəˈzɛs/verb [T] (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时)
1 (formal 正式) to have or own sth 具有；拥有: They lost everything they possessed in the fire. 他们在火灾中失去所有财产。 Paola possesses a natural ability to make people laugh. 保拉天生具有逗人发笑的本事。
2 to influence sb or to make sb do sth 影响（某人）；驱使（某人做某事）: What possessed you to say a thing like that! 究竟是什么使你说出那种话！
Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) Any student possessing the necessary qualifications will be considered for the course. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：Any student possessing the necessary qualifications will be considered for the course.凡是具备必要条件的学生，这门课程都会考虑取录。

*possession
/pəˈzeʃn ||; pəˈzɛʃən/noun
1 [U] the state of having or owning sth 有；持有；拥有；占有: The gang were caught in possession of stolen goods. 那帮人持有赃物，当场被捉。 Enemy forces managed to take possession of the town. 敌军攻占了那个市镇。
2 [C] [usu.pl] something that you have or own 所有物；财产；财物: Bud packed all his possessions and left. 巴德收拾好他的所有财物后便走了。

possessive
/pəˈzesɪv ||; pəˈzɛsɪv/adj
1 possessive (of/about sb/sth) not wanting to share sb/sth 不愿与人分享: Dan is so possessive with his toys -- he won't let other children play with them. 丹尼对于自己的玩具很吝啬─他不让别的孩子玩。
2 (grammar语法) used to describe words that show who or what a person or thing belongs to 属格的；所有格的: ‘My’, ‘your’ and ‘his’ are possessive adjectives. my、your、his是属格形容词。 ‘Mine’, ‘yours’ and ‘his’ are possessive pronouns. mine、yours、his是属格代名词。

possessor
/pəˈzesə(r) ||; pəˈzɛsɚ/noun [C] a person who has or owns sth 持有人；拥有者

*possibility
/ˌpɒsəˈbɪləti ||; ˌpɑsəˈbɪlətɪ/noun (plural possibilities)
1 [U] [C] (a) possibility (of sth/doing sth);(a) possibility that... the fact that sth might exist or happen, but is not likely to 可能的情况；可能；可能性: There's not much possibility of the letter reaching you before Saturday. 星期六之前那封信寄到你手上的可能性不大。 There is a strong possibility that the fire was started deliberately. 那场大火的起因很有可能是有人蓄意纵火。
2 [C] one of the different things that you can do in a particular situation or in order to achieve sth （在某情况下或为达成某事的）办法: There is a wide range of possibilities open to us. 我们可以使用各种各样的办法。

*possible
/ˈpɒsəbl ||; ˈpɑsəbḷ/adj
1 that can happen or be done 可能发生或做到的；可能的: I'll phone you back as soon as possible. 我会尽快回电话给你。 Could you give me your answer today, if possible ? 可能的话，今天答复我好吗？ The doctors did everything possible to save his life. 医生们尽了一切办法挽救他的生命。 You were warned of all the possible dangers. 已经警告过你所有可能发生的危险。 [OPP] impossible 反义词为impossible
2 that may be suitable or acceptable 可能合适的；可以接受的: There are four possible candidates for the job. 这个职位有四名可能合适的人选。 ☞Look at probable. 参看probable。
3 used after adjectives to emphasize that sth is the best, worst, etc of its type （置于形容词后，强调某事是同类中最好、最差等）: Alone and with no job or money, I was in the worst possible situation. 孑然一身，既无工作又无钱，我处于极其糟糕的境地。

possibly
/ˈpɒsəbli ||; ˈpɑsəblɪ/adv
1 perhaps; maybe 也许；或许: ‘Will you be free on Sunday?’ ‘Possibly.’ “星期日你有空吗？”“也许有。”
2 (used for emphasizing sth) according to what is possible （用于强调）可能: I will leave as soon as I possibly can. 我会尽快离开。

post-
/pəʊst ||; post/prefix (used in nouns, verbs and adjectives 用于构成名词、动词及形容词) after 在…之后: postgraduate 研究生 post-war 战后 ☞Look at ante- and pre-. 参看ante-及pre-。

*post¹
/pəʊst ||; post/noun
1 (especially US 尤为美 mail) [U] the system or organization for collecting and dealing with letters, packages, etc 邮政；邮递: The document is too valuable to send by post. 这文件太重要了，不可用邮递方式送去。 If you hurry you might catch the post (= post it before everything is collected). 要是你快一点，也许能赶上收信时间。
2 (US 美 mail) [U] letters, packages, etc that are collected or brought to your house 邮件；信件: Has the post come yet this morning? 今早邮件到了没有？ There wasn't any post for you. 没有你的信件。
3 [C] a job 职位；工作: The post was advertised in the local newspaper. 那个职位的招聘广告登在本地的报纸上。 [SYN] position 同义词为position
4 [C] a place where sb is on duty or is guarding sth 岗位；哨所；驻守地: The soldiers had to remain at their posts all night. 士兵们不得不彻夜留在哨所。
5 [C] an upright piece of metal or wood that is put in the ground to mark a position or to support sth 柱；杆: a goal post 球门柱 Can you see a signpost anywhere? 你能不能在什么地方看到路标呢？
by return (of post)→RETURN²
*post²
/pəʊst ||; post/verb[T]
1 (especially US 尤为美 mail) to send a letter, package, etc by post 投寄；邮寄: This letter was posted in Edinburgh yesterday. 这封信昨天在爱丁堡寄出。
Post (noun and verb) is more commonly used in British English and mail in American English. However, British English also uses the noun mail quite often. The official name of the Post Office organization is the Royal Mail. Note too, the expressions airmail and surface mail. When we order goods in a letter, we use a mail-order service. post（名词及动词）较常用于英国英语，美国英语以mail较为常用。但是，作名词用的mail在英国英语中也相当常用，英国邮政机关的正式名称就是Royal Mail。同时请注意airmail（空邮）及surface mail（平邮）等用语。邮购服务称为mail-order service。
2 to send sb to go and work somewhere 委派某人去某地工作: After two years in London, Rosa was posted to the Tokyo office. 在伦敦工作了两年后，罗莎被派往东京办事处工作。
3 to put sb on guard or on duty in a particular place 使驻守；使站岗: Policemen were posted outside the building. 警察部署在建筑物外面站岗。
4 (formal 正式) (often passive 常用于被动语态) to put a notice where everyone can see it 张贴（通告）: The exam results will be posted on the main noticeboard. 考试成绩将会张贴在主要布告板上。

postage
/ˈpəʊstɪdʒ ||; ˈpostɪdʒ/noun [U] the amount that you must pay to send a letter, package etc 邮资；邮费

ˈpostage stamp
=STAMP¹(1)

*postal
/ˈpəʊstl ||; ˈpostḷ/adj connected with the sending and collecting of letters, packages, etc 邮政的；邮务的；邮递的

ˈpostal code
noun [C] = postcode

ˈpostal order
noun [C] a piece of paper that you can buy at a post office that represents a certain amount of money. A postal order is a safe way of sending money by post. 邮局汇款单；邮政汇票

postbox
/ˈpəʊstbɒks ||; ˈpostˌbɑks/ (also letter box) (US 美 mailbox) noun [C] a box in a public place where you put letters, etc that you want to send 邮筒；邮箱 ☞Look at pillar box. 参看pillar box。

postcard
/ˈpəʊstkɑ:d ||; ˈpostˌkɑrd/noun [C] a card that you write a message on and send to sb. Postcards have a picture on one side and are usually sent without an envelope. 明信片

postcode
/ˈpəʊstkəʊd ||; ˈpostˌkod/ (US 美 ZIP code) noun [C] a group of letters and/or numbers that you put at the end of an address 邮政编码；邮政编码

*poster
/ˈpəʊstə(r) ||; ˈpostɚ/noun[C]
1 a large printed picture or a notice in a public place, often used to advertise sth 招贴；海报；大幅广告
2 a large picture printed on paper that is put on a wall for decoration 招贴画

posterity
/pɒˈsterəti ||; pɑsˈtɛrətɪ/noun [U] the future and the people who will be alive then 后裔；子孙；后代: We should look after our environment for the sake of posterity. 为了后代，我们应该保护环境。

postgraduate
/ˌpəʊstˈgrædʒuət ||; postˈgrædʒυɪt/noun [C] a person who is doing further studies at a university after taking his/her first degree 研究生 ☞Look at graduate and undergraduate. 参看graduate及undergraduate。

posthumous
/ˈpɒstjʊməs; US ˈpɒstʃəməs ||; ˈpɑstʃυməs/adj given or happening after sb has died 死后（给予或发生）的；身后的: a posthumous medal for bravery 死后追颁的英勇奖章 ➔posthumously adv

posting
/ˈpəʊstɪŋ ||; ˈpostɪŋ/noun [C] a job in another country that you are sent to do by your employer 受雇主派往国外工作的职位

ˈPost-it™
(also Post-it note) noun [C] a small piece of coloured, sticky paper that you use for writing a note on, and that can be easily removed 报事贴；便条纸 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图

postman
/ˈpəʊstmən ||; ˈpostmən/ (US 美 mailman) noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a person whose job is to collect letters, packages, etc and take them to people's houses 邮差；邮递员

postmark
/ˈpəʊstmɑ:k ||; ˈpostˌmɑrk/noun [C] an official mark over a stamp on a letter, package, etc that says when and where it was posted 邮戳

postmodernism
/ˌpəʊstˈmɒdənɪzəm ||; ˌpostˈmɑdɚnˌɪzəm/noun [U] a style and movement in art, architecture, literature, etc in the late 20th century that reacts against modern styles, e.g. by mixing features from traditional and modern styles 后现代主义﹙20 世纪后期在艺术、建筑、文学等方面对抗现代风格、融合了传统与现代风格的运动﹚ ➔postmodernist /ˌpəʊstˈmɒdənɪst ||; ˌpost ˈmɑdɚnɪst/ noun [C],adj (also postmodern): postmodernist culture/writing/cinema 后现代文化/作品/电影

post-mortem
/ˌpəʊst ˈmɔ:təm ||; post ˈmɔrtəm/noun [C] a medical examination of a dead body to find out how the person died 验尸

post-natal
/ˌpəʊst ˈneɪtl ||; post ˈnetḷ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with the period after the birth of a baby 产后的；分娩后的 [OPP] antenatal 反义词为antenatal

ˈpost office
noun [C]
1 a place where you can buy stamps, post packages, etc 邮局（指地方）
2 the Post Office the national organization that is responsible for collecting and dealing with letters, packages, etc 邮政局（指机构）

postpone
/pəˈspəʊn ||; posˈpon/verb [T] to arrange that sth will happen at a later time than the time you had planned; to delay 使延期；延迟；延缓: The match was postponed because of water on the pitch. 比赛因球场积水而延期。 ☞Look at cancel. 参看cancel。 ➔postponement noun [C,U]

postscript
/ˈpəʊstskrɪpt ||; ˈpostskrɪpt/noun [C] an extra message or extra information that is added at the end of a letter, note, etc （信、便笺等后面附加的）附笔，又及，再启 ☞Look at PS. 参看PS。

posture
/ˈpɒstʃə(r) ||; ˈpɑstʃɚ/noun [C,U] the way that a person sits, stands, walks, etc 姿态；姿势: Poor posture can lead to backache. 不适当的姿势可引致背痛。

ˌpost-ˈwar
adj existing or happening in the period after the end of a war, especially the Second World War 战后的（尤指第二次世界大战之后的）

*pot¹
/pɒt ||; pɑt/noun[C]
1 a round container that is used for cooking food in （用于煮食的）锅
2 a container that you use for a particular purpose 罐；壶；盆；瓶: a flowerpot 花盆 a pot of paint 一罐油漆
3 the amount that a pot contains 一罐，一壶（的量）: We drank two pots of tea. 我们喝了两壶茶。
pot²
/pɒt ||; pɑt/verb [T] (potting;potted)
1 to put a plant into a pot filled with soil 把（植物）栽种于花盆内
2 to hit a ball into one of the pockets in the table in the game of POOL, BILLIARDS or SNOOKER （玩落袋台球时）击（球）入袋: He potted the black ball into the corner pocket. 他把黑球击入角上的袋中。

potable
/ˈpəʊtəbl ||; ˈpotəbḷ/adj (formal 正式) (used about water 指水) safe to drink 可安全饮用的；适合饮用的

potassium
/pəˈtæsiəm ||; pəˈtæsɪəm/noun [U] (symbol K) a soft silver-white metal that exists mainly in mixtures(compounds)which are used in industry and farming 钾

*potato
/pəˈteɪtəʊ ||; pəˈteto/noun [C,U] (plural potatoes) a round vegetable that grows under the ground with a brown, yellow or red skin. Potatoes are white or yellow inside 马铃薯；土豆: mashed potato 土豆泥 to peel potatoes 削马铃薯皮 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

potato ˈcrisp
(US 美 poˈtato chip)=CRISP²

potent
/ˈpəʊtnt ||; ˈpotṇt/adj strong or powerful 强而有力的；浓烈的；有强效的；有权势的: a potent drug/drink 特效药；烈酒 ➔potency /-nsi ||; -ṇsɪ/ noun [U]

*potential¹
/pəˈtenʃl ||; pəˈtɛnʃəl/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that may possibly become sth, happen, be used, etc 可能的；潜在的: Wind power is a potential source of energy. 风力是一种潜在的能源。 potential customers 有可能成为顾客的人 ➔potentially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv
potential²
/pəˈtenʃl ||; pəˈtɛnʃəl/noun [U] the qualities or abilities that sb/sth has but that may not be fully developed yet 潜力；潜能；潜质: That boy has great potential as an athlete. 那男孩极具成为运动员的潜力。

poˌtential ˈenergy
noun [U] (technical术语) the form of energy that an object gains as it is lifted 势能 ☞picture at energy 见energy插图

pothole
/ˈpɒthəʊl ||; ˈpɑtˌhol/noun[C]
1 a hole in the surface of a road that is formed by traffic and bad weather （路面上因来往车辆或坏天气而形成的）凹坑，小坑，坑洞
2 a deep hole in rock that is formed by water over thousands of years and often leads to underground rooms (caves) 壶穴，锅穴，瓯穴（岩石几千年来被水侵蚀而形成的深洞，多通至地下洞穴）

potholing
/ˈpɒthəʊlɪŋ ||; ˈpɑtˌholɪŋ/noun [U] the sport of climbing down inside potholes(2), walking through underground tunnels, etc 洞穴探索运动: to go potholing 进行洞穴探索

potion
/pəʊʃn ||; ˈpoʃən/noun [C] (used especially in stories) a drink of medicine or poison; a liquid with magic powers ﹙尤用于故事﹚药水，毒液，魔水: a magic/love potion 魔水；春药饮剂

potluck
/pɒtˈlʌk ||; pɑtˈlʌk/noun [C] (US 美) a meal to which each guest brings some food, which is then shared out among the guests 百乐餐﹙参加者各带食物与众人分享﹚ take potluck
1 to have to choose sth from what is available and hope that it will be good or acceptable 接受现成的东西；有什么选什么: He'd have to take potluck in a town not noted for its hotels.在这个不以酒店出名的城市，他只好随便选一家了。
2 to have a meal at sb's home in which you eat whatever he/she has available 吃家常便饭；有什么吃什么  potluck adj: a potluck meal/supper百乐餐

ˈpot plant
noun [C] (Brit 英) a plant that you keep indoors 盆栽

pot-pourri
/ˌpəʊ pʊˈri: ||; ˌpo pəˈri/noun
1 [C,U] a mixture of dried flowers and leaves used for making a room smell pleasant 百花香﹙可使房间馨香的干花﹚
2 [sing] a mixture of various things that were not originally intended to form a group 杂集；杂曲: a pot-pourri of tunes 集锦曲

potshot
/pɒtʃɒt ||; ˈpɑtˌʃɑt/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a shot that sb fires without aiming carefully 乱射；盲目的射击: Somebody took a potshot at him as he drove past. 他开车经过时，有人向他乱开了一枪。 (figurative 比喻) The newspapers took constant potshots at (= criticized) the President.报界经常恣意批评总统。

potter¹
/ˈpɒtə(r) ||; ˈpɑtɚ/ (US 美 putter /ˈpʌtə(r) ||; ˈpʌtɚ/) verb [I] potter (about/around) to spend your time doing small jobs or things that you enjoy without hurrying 慢条斯理地做琐碎的事: Grandpa spends most of the day pottering in the garden. 爷爷在花园里慢慢吞吞地拾掇了大半天。
potter²
/ˈpɒtə(r) ||; ˈpɑtɚ/noun [C] a person who makes pots, dishes, etc (pottery) from baked clay 陶工；制陶工人

pottery
/ˈpɒtəri ||; ˈpɑtərɪ/noun (plural potteries)
1 [U] pots, dishes, etc that are made from baked clay 陶器；陶瓷器皿
2 [U] the activity or skill of making dishes, etc from clay 陶器制造；陶艺: a pottery class 陶艺班
3 [C] a place where clay pots and dishes are made 陶器厂；陶器作坊

potty¹
/ˈpɒti ||; ˈpɑtɪ/adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式)
1 crazy or silly 疯狂的；愚蠢的
2 potty about sb/sth liking sb/sth very much 对…着迷；极喜欢: Penny's potty about Mark. 彭尼迷上了马克。
potty²
/ˈpɒti ||; ˈpɑtɪ/noun [C] (plural potties) a plastic bowl that young children use when they are too small to use a toilet （幼儿用）便盆，尿壶

pouch
/paʊtʃ ||; paυtʃ/noun[C]
1 a small leather bag 小皮囊
2 a pocket of skin on the stomach of some female animals, for example KANGAROOS, in which they carry their babies （袋鼠等有袋动物的）育儿袋 ☞picture at marsupial 见marsupial插图

poultice
/ˈpəʊltɪs ||; ˈpoltɪs/noun [C] a soft substance that you spread on a cloth and put on the skin to reduce pain or swelling 泥罨剂；膏药

poultry
/ˈpəʊltri ||; ˈpoltrɪ/noun
1 [pl] birds, for example chickens, ducks, etc that are kept for their eggs or their meat 家禽（如鸡、鸭等）
2 [U] the meat from these birds 家禽的肉: Eat plenty of fish and poultry. 要吃许多鱼和禽肉。

pounce
/paʊns ||; paυns/verb [I] pounce (on sb/sth) to attack sb/sth by jumping suddenly on him/her/it 猛扑；突袭 (figurative 比喻) He was quick to pounce on any mistakes I made. 他很快便抓住我所犯的任何错误。

*pound¹
/paʊnd ||; paυnd/noun
1 [C] (also ˌpound ˈsterling) (symbol £) the unit of money in Britain; one hundred pence (100p) 英镑（英国货币单位，1英镑等于100便士）: Melissa earns £16000 a year. 梅利莎每年挣16000英镑。 Can you change a ten-pound note? 可以给我换开一张十英镑的纸币吗？ a pound coin 面额一英镑的硬币
2 [sing] the pound the value of the British pound on international money markets 英镑在国际货币市场上的价值: The pound has fallen against the dollar. 英镑兑美元下跌。 How many yen are there to the pound ? 多少日元兑换一英镑？
3 [C] (abbr lb) a measurement of weight; equal to 0.454 of a kilogram 磅（重量单位，1磅等于0.454克）: The carrots cost 30p a pound. 胡萝卜30便士一磅。 Half a pound of mushrooms, please. 请给我半磅蘑菇。 ☞For more information about measurements look at the special section on numbers at the back of this dictionary. 有关度量衡的详细用法，参看本词典末数词用法部份。
pound²
/paʊnd ||; paυnd/verb
1 [I] pound (at/against/on sth) to hit sth hard many times making a lot of noise （砰砰地）重击，打击: She pounded on the door with her fists. 她用拳头砰砰地敲门。
2 [I] pound along, down, up, etc to walk with heavy, noisy steps in a particular direction 脚步发出沉重响声地走: Jason went pounding up the stairs three at a time. 贾森一步三级，嗵嗵地跑上楼梯。
3 [I] (used about your heart, blood, etc) to beat quickly and loudly （指心脏、血液等）疾跳，砰砰地搏动: Her heart was pounding with fear. 她吓得心砰砰直跳。
4 [T] to hit sth many times to break it into smaller pieces 捣碎

*pour
/pɔ:(r) ||; pɔr/verb
1 [T] to make a liquid or other substance flow steadily out of or into a container 灌；注；倒: Pour the sugar into a bowl. 把糖倒进碗内。
2 [I] (used about a liquid, smoke, light, etc) to flow out of or into sth quickly and steadily, and in large quantities （指液体、烟雾、光线等）倾泻: Tears were pouring down her cheeks. 泪水汩汩地从她的脸颊淌下。 She opened the curtains and sunlight poured into the room. 她拉开窗帘，阳光泻进房间。
3 [T] pour sth (out) to serve a drink to sb by letting it flow from a container into a cup or glass 给…倒或斟（饮料）: Have you poured out the tea? 你斟了茶没有？
4 [I] pour (down) (with rain) to rain heavily 下倾盆大雨: The rain poured down all day long. 一整天都下着倾盆大雨。 I'm not going out. It's pouring with rain. 我不出去了，下着大雨呢。
5 [I] to come or go somewhere continuously in large numbers 涌向；蜂拥（而至）: People were pouring out of the station. 人们涌出车站。
pour your heart out (to sb) to tell sb all your personal problems, feelings, etc （向某人）倾诉（问题、感受等） pour sth out to speak freely about what you think or feel about sth that has happened to you 尽情地谈论（对某事的想法或感受）: to pour out all your troubles 把你所有的烦恼都说出来

pout
/paʊt ||; paυt/verb [I] to push your lips, or your bottom lip, forward to show that you are annoyed about sth or to look sexually attractive 撅嘴（以表示不悦或显得性感） pout noun [C]

*poverty
/ˈpɒvəti ||; ˈpɑvɚtɪ/noun [U] the state of being poor 贫穷；贫困: There are millions of people in this country who are living in poverty. 这个国家有数百万人过着贫困的生活。

poverty-stricken
/ˈpɒvəti strɪkən ||; ˈpɑvɚtɪ ˌstrɪkən/adj very poor 极贫穷的

POW
/ˌpi: əʊ ˈdʌblju: ||; ˌpi o ˈdʌblju/abbr prisoner of war 战俘

*powder
/ˈpaʊdə(r) ||; ˈpaυdɚ/noun [U] [C] a dry substance that is in the form of very small grains 粉；粉末: washing powder 洗衣粉 Grind the spices into a fine powder. 把这些香料研成粉末。 powder verb [T]

powdered
/ˈpaʊdəd ||; ˈpaυdɚd/adj (used about a substance that is usually liquid) dried and made into powder （一般指液体）弄干成粉状的: powdered milk/soup 奶粉；粉状汤料

*power¹
/ˈpaʊə(r) ||; ˈpaυɚ/noun
1 [U] power (over sb/sth);power (to do sth) the ability to control people or things or to do sth （控制人、物或做某事的）能力，权力，影响力: The aim is to give people more power over their own lives. 目的是为了给人们更多支配自己生活的权力。 to have sb in your power 控制某人 It's not in my power (= I am unable)to help you. 我无力帮你的忙。
2 [U] political control of a country or area （控制国家或地区的）政权: When did this government come to power ? 这个政府是什么时候上台执政的？ to take/seize power 执政；夺取政权
3 [C] the power (to do sth) the right or authority to do sth 权力；权限；职权: Do the police have the power to stop cars without good reason? 如果没有充分理由，警察有权拦下车辆吗？
4 [C] a country with a lot of influence in world affairs or that has great military strength （在世界事务中很有影响力或有强大军事实力的）强国，大国: a military/economic power 军事╱经济大国 ☞Look at superpower and world power. 参看superpower及world power。
5 powers [pl] a particular ability of the body or mind 身心的某种能力: He has great powers of observation. 他有很强的观察力。 She had to use all her powers of persuasion on him. 她不得不对他使出全部劝服力。
6 [U] the energy or strength that sb/sth has 力；力量: The ship was helpless against the power of the storm. 那艘船无法抵抗风暴。 I've lost all power in my right arm. 我的右臂完全使不出力。
7 [U] energy that can be collected and used for operating machines, making electricity, etc 动力；能源: nuclear/wind/solar power 核能；风能；太阳能 This car has power steering. 这辆车有动力转向系统。
power²
/ˈpaʊə(r) ||; ˈpaυɚ/verb [T] to supply energy to sth to make it work 给某物提供动力: What powers the motor in this machine? 这台机器的马达是什么驱动的？ ➔-powered adj a solar-powered calculator 太阳能计算器 a high-powered engine 马力大的引擎

ˈpower cut
noun [C] a time when the supply of electricity stops, for example during a storm 停电，供电中断（比如暴风雨时）

powerless
/ˈpaʊələs ||; ˈpaυɚləs/adj
1 without strength, influence or control 无力的；无影响力的；无控制力的
2 powerless to do sth completely unable to do sth 无能为力: I stood and watched him struggle, powerless to help. 我站着，眼巴巴看着他挣扎却无力救助。

ˈpower point
(Brit 英) =SOCKET(1)

ˈpower station
(US 美 power plant) noun [C] a place where electricity is made (generated) 发电站；发电厂

*powerful
/ˈpaʊəfl ||; ˈpaυɚfəl/adj
1 having a lot of control or influence over other people 有权力的；有影响力的: a powerful nation 强国 He's one of the most powerful directors in Hollywood. 他是好莱坞最有影响的导演之一。
2 having great strength or force 强健的；强劲的；大功率的: a powerful car/engine/telescope 大功率汽车；大功率引擎；高倍望远镜 a powerful swimmer 游泳健将
3 having a strong effect on your mind or body （对身心）影响大的，效力大的: The Prime Minister made a powerful speech. 首相发表了一篇很有说服力的演说。 a powerful drug 强效药物 ➔powerfully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv

pp
abbr
1 pp. pages 页: See pp. 100-178. 见第100至178页。
2 (also p.p.) (before a signature) used to mean ‘on behalf of’ （放在署名前）代行: pp Mike Holland(= from Mike Holland but signed by sb else because he is away) 代迈克．霍兰行（即由迈克˙霍兰发出，但因本人外出，由他人代签）

PR
/ˌpi: ˈɑ:(r) ||; ˌpi ˈɑr/abbr
1 public relations 公共关系；公关
2 proportional representation 比例代表制

practicable
/ˈpræktɪkəbl ||; ˈpræktɪkəbḷ/adj (used about an idea, a plan or a suggestion) able to be done successfully （指主意、计划或建议）可行的，行得通的，能实行的: The scheme is just not practicable. 这个计划根本不可行。 [OPP] impracticable 反义词为impracticable

*practical¹
/ˈpræktɪkl ||; ˈpræktɪkḷ/adj
1 concerned with actually doing sth rather than with ideas or thought 实际的: Have you got any practical experience of working on a farm? 你有没有在农场工作的实际经验？ ☞Look at theoretical. 参看theoretical。
2 that is likely to succeed; right or sensible 可成功的；可行的；行得通的: We need to find a practical solution to the problem. 对这个问题我们须要找个可行的解决办法。
3 very suitable for a particular purpose; useful 切合实际的；有用的；实用的: a practical little car, ideal for the city 一辆很适用于城市的实用小型车
4 (used about people) making sensible decisions and good at dealing with problems （指人）实事求是，能作出明智决定，善于处理问题: We must be practical. It's no good buying a house we cannot afford. 我们必须实事求是─买一幢我们负担不起的房子是不明智的。 [OPP] for senses 2, 3 and 4 impractical 第2、3及4义的反义词皆为impractical
5 (used about a person) good at making and repairing things （指人）手巧，善于制作和修理东西: Brett's very practical and has made a lot of improvements to their new house. 布雷特手很巧，已经对他们的新房子作了很多改善。
practical²
/ˈpræktɪkl ||; ˈpræktɪkḷ/noun [C] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) a lesson or an exam where you do or make sth rather than just writing 实习课；实习考试: He passed the theory paper but failed the practical. 理论试卷他及格了，但实习考试不及格。

practicality
/ˌpræktɪˈkæləti ||; ˌpræktɪˈkælətɪ/ (plural practicalities) noun
1 [U] the quality of being suitable and realistic, or likely to succeed 实用性；实际性；可行性: I am not convinced of the practicality of the scheme. 我不相信这项计划行得通。
2 practicalities [pl] the real facts rather than ideas or thoughts 实际事物，实例（而非理念或思想）: Let's look at the practicalities of the situation. 我们来看看实际情况吧。

ˌpractical ˈjoke
noun [C] a trick that you play on sb that makes him/her look silly and makes other people laugh 恶作剧

practically
/ˈpræktɪkli ||; ˈpræktɪkḷɪ/adv
1 (spoken 口语) almost; very nearly 几乎；差不多: My essay is practically finished now. 我的作文现在差不多写好了。
2 in a realistic or sensible way 切合实际；明智

*practice
/ˈpræktɪs ||; ˈpræktɪs/noun
1 [U] action rather than ideas or thought 实践；行动: the theory and practice of language teaching 语言教学的理论与实践 I can't wait to put what I've learnt into practice. 我迫不及待要把我所学的付诸实践。
2 [C,U] (formal 正式) the usual or expected way of doing sth in a particular organization or situation; a habit or custom 惯常做法；习惯；习俗: It is standard practice not to pay bills until the end of the month. 惯常的做法是到月底才付账。
3 [C,U] (a period of) doing an activity many times or training regularly so that you become good at it 练习；进行练习的一段时间: piano/football practice 练习弹钢琴╱踢足球 His accent should improve with practice. 只要多练习，他的口音应能改善。
4 [U] the work of a doctor or lawyer 医生或律师的工作: Dr Roberts doesn't work in a hospital. He's in general practice (= he's a family doctor). 罗伯茨医生不是在医院里工作，他自己开业当全科医生（他是个家庭医生）。
5 [C] the business of a doctor, dentist or lawyer 医生、牙医或律师的业务或执业: a successful medical/dental practice 成功的医业╱牙医业
be/get out of practice to find it difficult to do sth because you have not done it for a long time 疏于练习: I'm not playing very well at the moment. I'm really out of practice. 我目前弹得不好，我确实疏于练习。 in practice in reality 实际上: Prisoners have legal rights, but in practice these rights are not always respected. 囚犯享有法定权利，但这种权利实际上并不总是受到尊重。

*practise
/ˈpræktɪs ||; ˈpræktɪs/ (US 美 practice) verb [I,T]
1 to do an activity or train regularly so that you become very good at sth 练习: If you want to play a musical instrument well, you must practise every day. 如果你乐器想演奏得好，你必须天天练习。 He always wants to practise his English onme. 他老是想跟我练习英语。
2 to do sth or take part in sth regularly or publicly （经常或公开地）做，参与: a practising Catholic/Jew/Muslim 虔诚的天主教徒╱犹太教徒╱穆斯林
3 practise (sth/as sth) to work as a doctor or lawyer （医生或律师）开业，执业: She's practising as a barrister in Leeds. 他在利兹当律师。 He was banned from practising medicine. 他被禁止行医。

practised
/ˈpræktɪst ||; ˈpræktɪst/ (US 美 practiced) adj practised (in sth) very good at sth, because you have done it a lot or often 精通；善于；熟练: He was practised in the art of inventing excuses. 他制造借口挺有本事。

practising ( US 美 practicing)
/præktɪsɪŋ ||; ˈpræktɪsɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) taking an active part in a particular religion/profession etc 积极履行业务的；热心的；虔诚的: a practising Christian/teacher 热心的基督徒/教师

practitioner
/prækˈtɪʃənə(r) ||; prækˈtɪʃənɚ/noun [C] (formal 正式) a person who works as a doctor, dentist or lawyer 执业医生、牙医或律师 ☞Look at GP. 参看GP。

pragmatic
/prægˈmætɪk ||; prægˈmætɪk/adj dealing with problems in a practical way rather than by following ideas or principles 实事求是的；实干的；务实的

pragmatism
/ˈprægmətɪzəm ||; ˈprægməˌtɪzəm/noun [U] (formal 正式) thinking about solving problems in a practical and sensible way rather than by having fixed ideas 实效主义；实用主义 ➔pragmatist /-tɪst ||; -tɪst/ noun [C]: Most successful teachers are pragmatists and realists. 成功的教师大多是实效主义者和现实主义者。

prairie
/ˈpreəri ||; ˈprɛrɪ/noun [C] a very large area of flat land covered in grass with few trees (especially in North America) 大草原（尤指北美洲的）

*praise¹
/preɪz ||; prez/verb [T] praise sb/sth (for sth) to say that sb/sth is good and should be admired 赞扬；称赞: The fireman was praised for his courage. 那消防员因表现英勇而获得嘉许。
*praise²
/preɪz ||; prez/noun [U] what you say when you are expressing admiration for sb/sth 赞扬；赞许: The survivors were full of praise for the paramedics. 幸存者对医护人员赞不绝口。

praiseworthy
/ˈpreɪzwɜ:ði ||; ˈprezˌwɝðɪ/adj that should be admired and recognized as good 值得赞扬的；可嘉的

pram
/præm ||; præm/ (US 美 baby carriage) noun [C] a small vehicle on four wheels for a young baby, pushed by a person on foot 手推婴儿车

prance
/prɑ:ns; US præns ||; præns/verb [I] to move about with quick, high steps, often because you feel proud or pleased with yourself 雀跃；欢欣地跳跃；轻快地走

prank
/præŋk ||; præŋk/noun [C] a trick that is played on sb as a joke 玩笑；恶作剧: a childish/silly prank 幼稚的/愚蠢的恶作剧 ➔prankster /ˈpræŋkstə(r) ||; ˈpræŋkstɚ/ noun [C]: Student pranksters have done considerable damage to the school buildings. 搞恶作剧的学生对学校的建筑造成相当大的损坏。

prat
/præt ||; præt/noun [C] (Brit 英) (slang 俚语) a stupid person 傻瓜；笨蛋: What a prat! 真是个笨蛋！

prawn
/prɔ:n ||; prɔn/ (US 美 shrimp) noun [C] a small shellfish that we eat and that becomes pink when cooked 虾；对虾；明虾 ☞Look at shrimp. 参看shrimp。 ☞picture at shellfish 见shellfish插图

*pray
/preɪ ||; pre/verb [I,T] pray (to sb) (for sb/sth) to speak to God or a god in order to give thanks or to ask for help 祈祷；祷告；祈求: They knelt down and prayed for peace. 他们跪下祈求和平。

*prayer
/preə(r) ||; prɛr/noun
1 [C] a prayer (for sb/sth) the words that you use when you speak to God or a god 祷文；祷词: Let's say a prayer for all the people who are ill. 我们为所有患病的人祈祷吧。 a prayer book 祈祷书
2 [U] the act of speaking to God or a god 祈祷；祷告: to kneel in prayer 跪下祈祷

pre-
/pri: ||; pri/prefix (used in verbs, nouns and adjectives 用于构成动词、名词及形容词) before 前；在前: prepay 预先付款 preview 预习 pre-war 战前 ☞Compare ante- and post-. 与ante-及post-比较。

preach
/pri:tʃ ||; pritʃ/verb
1 [I,T] to give a talk (a sermon) on a religious subject, especially in a church 讲道；布道；传教
2 [T] to say that sth is good and persuade other people to accept it 鼓吹；倡导；宣扬: I always preach caution in situations like this. 在这种情况下我总是主张小心谨慎。
3 [I] to give sb advice on how to behave, on what is considered morally acceptable, etc, in a way that he/she finds boring or annoying （令人厌烦或生气地）说教，训诫: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to preach. 对不起，我不是有意向你说教。

preacher
/ˈpri:tʃə(r) ||; ˈpritʃɚ/noun [C] a person who gives religious talks (sermons), for example in a church 传道者；讲道员

ˌpre-arˈranged
adj planned or arranged in advance 预先计划﹙或安排﹚的: a pre-arranged signal 事先约定的信号

precarious
/prɪˈkeəriəs ||; prɪˈkɛrɪəs/adj not safe or certain; dangerous 不稳定的；不确定的；危险的: Working on the roof of that building looks very precarious. 在那幢大楼的屋顶上干活看来很危险。 ➔precariously adv

precaution
/prɪˈkɔ:ʃn ||; prɪˈkɔʃən/noun [C] a precaution (against sth) something that you do now in order to avoid danger or problems in the future 预防，防备，防范（措施）: You should always take the precaution of locking your valuables in the hotel safe. 你始终应当采取防备措施，把贵重物品锁进旅馆的保险箱内。 precautions against fire/theft 防火╱防窃措施 ➔precautionary /prɪˈkɔ:ʃənəri; US -nerɪ ||; prɪˈkɔʃənˌɛrɪ/ adj

precede
/prɪˈsi:d ||; prɪˈsid/verb [I,T] (written 书面语) to happen, come or go before sb/sth 在…之前发生、来或去: Look at the table on the preceding page. 参看前一页的一览表。

precedence
/ˈpresɪdəns ||; ˈprɛsədəns/noun [U] precedence (over sb/sth) the right that sb/sth has to come before sb/sth else because he/she/it is more important 优先；优先权: In business, making a profit seems to take precedence over everything else. 在商业上，获取利润似乎比其他任何东西都来得重要。

precedent
/ˈpresɪdənt ||; ˈprɛsədənt/noun [C,U] an official action or decision that has happened in the past and that is considered as an example or rule to follow in the same situation later 先例；前例: We don't want to set a precedent by allowing one person to come in late or they'll all want to do it. 我们不想容许一个人迟到而开先例，不然的话所有人都会仿效的。 Such protests are without precedent in recent history. 这类抗议在最近的历史上是没有先例的。 ☞Look at unprecedented. 参看unprecedented。

precinct
/ˈpri:sɪŋkt ||; ˈprisɪŋkt/noun
1 [C] (Brit 英) a special area of shops in a town where cars are not allowed 城镇中禁止汽车驶入的商业区: a shopping precinct 购物区
2 [C] (US 美) a part of a town that has its own police station （有警察分局的）辖区，管区
3 precincts [pl] (formal 正式) the area near or around a building （建筑物的）周围地区: the hospital and its precincts 医院及其附近地区

*precious
/ˈpreʃəs ||; ˈprɛʃəs/adj
1 of great value (usually because it is rare or difficult to find) 贵重的，宝贵的（通常因罕有或稀少）: In overcrowded Hong Kong, every small piece of land is precious. 在过度拥挤的香港，每一小块土地都是很宝贵的。
2 loved very much 心爱的；受到珍爱的: The painting was very precious to her. 这幅画是她很珍爱的。

ˌprecious ˈmetal
noun [C] a metal which is very rare and valuable and often used in jewellery 贵金属: Gold and silver are precious metals. 金和银都是贵金属。

ˌprecious ˈstone
(also stone) noun [C] a stone which is very rare and valuable and often used in jewellery 宝石: diamonds and other precious stones 钻石及其他宝石

precipice
/ˈpresəpɪs ||; ˈprɛsəpɪs/noun [C] a very steep side of a high mountain or cliff 悬崖；峭壁

precipitate¹
/prɪˈsɪpɪteɪt ||; prɪˈsɪpəˌtet/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to make sth, especially sth bad, happen suddenly or sooner than it should 使突然或提前发生（尤指坏事）
2 precipitate sb/sth into sth to suddenly force sb/sth into a particular state or condition 使骤然处于或陷入（某状态）: The president's assassination precipitated the country into war. 暗杀总统事件使该国陷入战争状态。
precipitate²
/prɪˈsɪpɪtət ||; prɪˈsɪpətɪt/adj (formal 正式) (used about an action or a decision 指行动或决定) happening very quickly or suddenly and usually without enough care and thought 仓促的；轻率的 ➔precipitately adv
precipitate³
/prɪˈsɪpɪteɪt ||; prɪˈsɪpəˌtet/noun [C] (technical术语) a solid substance that has been separated from a liquid in a chemical process 沉淀物

precipitation
/prɪˌsɪpɪˈteɪʃn ||; prɪˌsɪpəˈteʃən/noun
1 [U] (technical术语) rain, snow, etc that falls; the amount of this that falls 所降的雨、雪等；降水量
2 [U] [C] a chemical process in which solid material is separated from a liquid 沉淀

precis
/ˈpreɪsi: ||; ˈpresi/noun [C,U] (plural precis /-si:z ||; -siz/) a short version of a speech or written text that contains only the most important points 提要；撮要；摘要；大纲；梗概 [SYN] summary 同义词为summary

*precise
/prɪˈsaɪs ||; prɪˈsaɪs/adj
1 clear and accurate 明确的；精确的；确切的: precise details/instructions/measurements 确切的细节；明确的指示；精确的尺寸 He's in his forties -- well, forty-four, to be precise. 他四十多岁─嗯，确切地说，四十四岁。 She couldn't be very precise about what her attacker was wearing. 她无法十分确切描述袭击她的人的衣着。 [OPP] imprecise 反义词为imprecise
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) exact; particular 恰好的；特定的: I'm sorry. I can't come just at this precise moment. 对不起，恰好这个时候我不能来。
3 (used about a person) taking care to get small details right （指人）一丝不苟的: He's very precise about his work. 他对工作一丝不苟。

*precisely
/prɪˈsaɪsli ||; prɪˈsaɪslɪ/adv
1 exactly 正好；恰好: The time is 10.03 precisely. 时间正好是10点零3分。 [SYN] exactly 同义词为exactly
2 used to emphasize that sth is very true or obvious 确实；明确: It's precisely because I care about you that I got so angry when you stayed out late. 就因为关心你，所以我才对你很晚还不回家感到如此生气。
3 (spoken 口语) (used for agreeing with a statement) yes, that is right （用于表示同意）对，正是如此: ‘So, if we don't book now, we probably won't get a flight?’ ‘Precisely.’ “这么说，如果我们现在不预订机票，就很可能搭不上飞机？”“说得对。”

precision
/prɪˈsɪʒn ||; prɪˈsɪʒən/noun [U] the quality of being clear or exact 明确（性）；准确（性）；精确（性）: The plans were drawn with great precision. 那设计图画得极为精确。

preclude
/prɪˈklu:d ||; prɪˈklud/verb [T] (formal 正式)preclude sth;preclude sb from doing sth to prevent sth from happening or sb from doing sth; to make sth impossible 阻止；妨碍: Lack of time precludes any further discussion. 由于没有时间，所以无法进一步讨论了。 His religious beliefs precluded him/his serving in the army. 他的宗教信仰使他无法在军队效力。

precocious
/prɪˈkəʊʃəs ||; prɪˈkoʃəs/adj (used about children) having developed certain abilities and ways of behaving at a much younger age than usual （指儿童）早熟的，过早发育的，少年老成的: a precocious child who started her acting career at the age of 5 一个从5岁就开始演出生涯的早熟孩子 ☞This word is often used in a critical way. 这个词常用于批评。

preconceived
/ˌpri:kənˈsi:vd ||; ˌprikənˈsivd/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used about an idea or opinion) formed before you have enough information or experience （指想法或意见）事先形成的，先入为主的

preconception
/ˌpri:kənˈsepʃn ||; ˌprikənˈsɛpʃən/noun [C] an idea or opinion that you have formed about sb/sth before you have enough information or experience 事先形成的看法；先入为主的意见；成见

precondition
/ˌpri:kənˈdɪʃn ||; ˌprikənˈdɪʃən/noun [C] (written 书面语)a precondition (for/of sth) something that must happen or exist before sth else can exist or be done 前提；先决条件 [SYN] prerequisite 同义词为prerequisite

ˌpre-ˈcooked
adj (used about food) prepared and partly cooked in advance so that it can be quickly heated and eaten later ﹙食物﹚预先烹制的，预煮的

predator
/ˈpredətə(r) ||; ˈprɛdətɚ/noun [C] an animal that kills and eats other animals 捕食其他动物为生的动物；食肉动物

predatory
/ˈpredətri ||; ˈprɛdəˌtɔrɪ/adj
1 (technical术语) (used about an animal 指动物) living by killing and eating other animals 以捕食其他动物为生的；食肉的
2 (written 书面语) (used about a person 指人) using weaker people for his/her own financial or sexual advantage 损人利己的

predecessor
/ˈpri:dɪsesə(r); US ˈpredə- ||; ˈprɛdɪˌsɛsɚ/noun[C]
1 the person who was in the job or position before the person who is in it now 前任；前辈: The new head teacher is much better than her predecessor. 新上任的校长远比她的前任好。
2 a thing such as a machine, that has been followed or replaced by sth else 被取代的事物；前身: This computer has a larger memory than its predecessors. 这台计算机比原先的储存量大。 ☞Look at successor. 参看successor。

predetermine
/ˌpri:dɪˈtɜ:mɪn ||; ˌpridɪˈtɝmɪn/verb [T] (formal 正式) to decide sth in advance so that it does not happen by chance 预先决定；事先安排: The sex of the embryo is predetermined at fertilization. 胚胎的性别早在受精时就决定了。 The way in which surveys are run often predetermines the results that are obtained. 民意调查进行的方式常常预先决定了调查的结果。 ➔predetermined adj

predicament
/prɪˈdɪkəmənt ||; prɪˈdɪkəmənt/noun [C] an unpleasant and difficult situation that is hard to get out of 困境

predicative
/prɪˈdɪkətɪv; US ˈpredɪkeɪtɪv ||; ˈprɛdɪˌketɪv/adj (grammar语法) (used about an adjective 指形容词) not used before a noun 不用于名词前: You cannot say ‘an asleep child’ because ‘asleep’ is a predicative adjective. 不能说an asleep child，因为asleep是表语形容词。 An adjective thatcanbe used before a noun is called attributive. Many adjectives, for example ‘big’, can be either predicative or attributive The house is big. It's a big house. 能用于名词前的形容词叫做定语(attributive)。big等许多形容词既可作表语，也可作定语：The house is big.这房子很大。·It's a big house.这是一幢大房子。 ➔predicatively adv ‘Asleep’ can only be used predicatively. asleep只能用作表语。

*predict
/prɪˈdɪkt ||; prɪˈdɪkt/verb [T] to say that sth will happen in the future 预言；预测；预计: Scientists still cannot predict exactly when earthquakes will happen. 科学家仍然不能预测地震究竟会在什么时候发生。

predictable
/prɪˈdɪktəbl ||; prɪˈdɪktəbḷ/adj
1 that was or could be expected to happen 可预料的；可预计的: The match had a predictable result. 这场比赛的结果不出所料。
2 (used about a person) always behaving in a way that you would expect and therefore rather boring （指人）一成不变的: I knew you were going to say that -- you're so predictable. 我就知道你会这么说─你真是一成不变。 ➔predictably adv

prediction
/prɪˈdɪkʃn ||; prɪˈdɪkʃən/noun [C,U] saying what will happen; what sb thinks will happen 预言；预报；预告；预测: The exam results confirmed my predictions. 考试的结果证明我的预测是正确的。

predigested
/ˌpri:daɪˈdʒestɪd ||; ˌpridaɪˈdʒɛstɪd/adj (used about information) put in a simple form that is easy to understand ﹙信息﹚简化的，使易于理解的: predigested news 简化的新闻

predominance
/prɪˈdɒmɪnəns ||; prɪˈdɑmənəns/noun [sing] the state of being more important or greater in number than other people or things 主导地位；占优势；占多数: There is a predominance of Japanese tourists in Hawaii. 在夏威夷，日本游客占大多数。

predominant
/prɪˈdɒmɪnənt ||; prɪˈdɑmənənt/adj most noticeable, powerful or important 最显著的；最有势力的；最重要的；居主导地位的: The predominant colour was blue. 主色是蓝色。

predominantly
/prɪˈdɒmɪnəntli ||; prɪˈdɑmənəntlɪ/adv mostly; mainly 大都；主要: The population of the island is predominantly Spanish. 那岛上的居民大都是西班牙人。

predominate
/prɪˈdɒmɪneɪt ||; prɪˈdɑməˌnet/verb [I] (formal 正式)predominate (over sb/sth) to be most important or greatest in number 占主导地位；占优势；占多数: Private interest was not allowed to predominate over public good. 私利不得凌驾于公益之上。

preemie
/pri:mi ||; ˈprimɪ/noun [C] (US, informal 美，非正式) a baby that is born before the expected time (premature) 早产儿

ˌpre-ˈeminent
adj (formal 正式) more important, more successful or of a higher standard than others 杰出的；出类拔萃的；卓越的: a pre-eminent example of the artist's work 这位艺术家杰出的代表作 ➔pre-eminence noun [U]

pre-empt
/pri ˈempt ||; prɪ ˈɛmpt/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to prevent sth from happening by taking action to stop it 预先制止或防止: Her departure pre-empted any further questions. 她的离去使别人无法再追问下去。 A good training course will pre-empt many problems. 一门好的培训课程可以防止许多问题。
2 to do or say sth before sb else does 抢在某人前面做某事；先发制人: She was just about to apologize when he pre-empted her. 她正打算道歉，他却先道歉了。

pre-empt
/priˈempt ||; prɪˈɛmpt/verb[T]
1 to prevent sth from happening by taking action to stop it 防止；避免: Her departure pre-empted any further questions. 她的离去避免了任何新的提问。
2 to do or say sth before sb else does 抢在…之前做﹙或说﹚: She was just about to apologize when he pre-empted her. 她正想道歉，他却抢先说了。
3 to replace a planned programme on television 临时取代﹙电视节目单上的节目﹚: ‘Roseanne’ will be pre-empted by a special news bulletin. 《罗西恩》将会临时换成特别新闻简报。

preface
/ˈprefəs ||; ˈprɛfəs/noun [C] a written introduction to a book that explains what it is about or why it was written （书的）序言，前言

prefect
/ˈpri:fekt ||; ˈprifɛkt/noun [C] (Brit 英) an older girl or boy in a school who has special duties and responsibilities. Prefects often help to make sure that the younger schoolchildren behave properly. （学校的）级长，风纪，纠察

prefecture
/pri:fektʃə(r) ||; ˈprifɛktʃɚ/noun [C] an area of local government in some countries, e.g. Japan ﹙日本等国的﹚地方行政区域；省；县

*prefer
/prɪˈfɜ:(r) ||; prɪˈfɝ/verb [T] (preferring;preferred)prefer sth (to sth);prefer to do sth;prefer doing sth (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to choose sth rather than sth else; to like sth better 宁可选择；较喜欢；偏好: Would you prefer tea or coffee? 你喜欢喝茶还是咖啡？ Marianne prefers not to walk home on her own at night. 玛丽安娜不愿在晚上独自走路回家。 My parents would prefer me to study law at university. 父母比较希望我在大学修读法律。 ☞Notice the different ways that prefer can be used Helen prefers going by train to flying (= generally or usually). Helen would prefer to go by train rather than (to) fly (= on this occasion). 注意prefer的不同用法：Helen prefers going by train to flying.海伦宁愿乘火车都不想坐飞机（在一般或通常情况下）。·Helen would prefer to go by train than (to) fly.比起坐飞机，海伦宁愿乘火车去（这一次）。 ☞ Prefer is generally rather formal. Instead of Would you prefer tea or coffee? we can say Would you rather have tea or coffee? Instead of I prefer skating to skiing we can say I like skating better than skiing. 一般来说prefer是相当正式的用语。与其说：Would you prefer tea or coffee?你选择喝茶还是咖啡？不如说：Would you rather have tea or coffee?你想要茶还是咖啡？除了可以说：I prefer skating to skiing.比起滑雪，我还是喜欢溜冰。我们可以说：I like skating better than skiing.我喜爱溜冰甚于滑雪。 Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) Their elder son had gone to work in London, preferring not to join the family firm. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：Their elder son had gone to work in London, preferring not to join the family firm.他们的大儿子不愿进家族公司，已经去了伦敦工作。
preferable
/ˈprefrəbl ||; ˈprɛfrəbḷ/adj preferable (to sth/doing sth) better or more suitable 更好的；更合适的: Going anywhere is preferable to staying at home for the weekend. 周末去任何地方都比留在家里好。

preferably
/ˈprefrəbli ||; ˈprɛfrəblɪ/adv used to show which person or thing would be better or preferred, if you are given a choice 最好是；较好: Give me a ring tonight -- preferably after 7 o'clock. 今晚给我打个电话─最好在7点后。

preference
/ˈprefrəns ||; ˈprɛfrəns/noun
1 [C,U] (a) preference (for sth) an interest in or desire for one thing more than another 喜爱；偏爱: What you wear is entirely a matter of personal preference. 穿什么完全是个人喜好问题。 [sing] Please list your choices in order of preference (= put the things you want most first on the list). 请把你的选择按喜好程度列出。
2 [U] special treatment that you give to one person or group rather than to others 优先权；优待；优惠: When allocating accommodation, we will give preference to families with young children. 分配住房时，我们将优先考虑有年幼子女的家庭。

preferential
/ˌprefəˈrenʃl ||; ˌprɛfəˈrɛnʃəl/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) giving or showing special treatment to one person or group rather than to others 优先的；优待的；优惠的: I don't see why he should get preferential treatment -- I've worked here just as long as he has! 我不明白为什么他应该得到优待─我和他在这里一样工作了那么久！

prefix
/ˈpri:fɪks ||; ˈpriˌfɪks/noun [C] (grammar语法) a letter or group of letters that you put at the beginning of a word to change its meaning 前缀，词首（置于单词前以改变其意义的字母或一组字母） ☞Look at affix ² and suffix. 参看affix^2及suffix。

pregnancy
/ˈpregnənsi ||; ˈprɛgnənsɪ/noun (plural pregnancies) [U] [C] the state of being pregnant 怀孕；妊娠

*pregnant
/ˈpregnənt ||; ˈprɛgnənt/adj (used about a woman or female animal) having a baby developing in her body （指妇女或雌性动物）怀孕的，妊娠的: Liz is five months pregnant. 利兹怀孕五个月了。 to get pregnant 怀孕 ☞It is also possible to say Liz is expecting a baby or Liz is going to have a baby. 另可以说：Liz is expecting a baby.利兹怀孕了。或Liz is going to have a baby.利兹快生孩子了。

preheat
/ˌpri:ˈhi:t ||; priˈhit/verb [T] to heat an oven to a particular temperature before you put food in it to cook 使﹙烤箱﹚预热

prehensile
/prɪˈhensaɪl ||; prɪˈhɛnsḷ/adj (technical术语) (used about part of an animal's body) able to hold things （指动物身上某部位）能握、抓或缠住东西的，可盘卷的: the monkey's prehensile tail 猴子可盘卷的尾巴 ☞picture at primate 见primate插图

prehistoric
/ˌpri:hɪˈstɒrɪk; US -ˈstɔ:rɪk ||; ˌprihɪsˈtɔrɪk/adj from the time in history before events were written down 有历史记载以前的；史前的

*prejudice¹
/ˈpredʒudɪs ||; ˈprɛdʒədɪs/noun [C,U] prejudice (against sb/sth) a strong unreasonable feeling of not liking or trusting sb/sth, especially when it is based on his/her/its race, religion or sex （尤指基于种族、宗教或性别的）偏见，成见，歧视: a victim of racial prejudice 种族偏见的受害者
prejudice²
/ˈpredʒudɪs ||; ˈprɛdʒədɪs/verb[T]
1 prejudice sb (against sb/sth) to influence sb so that he/she has an unreasonable or unfair opinion about sb/sth 使产生偏见: The newspaper stories had prejudiced the jury against him. 那些新闻报道使陪审团对他产生偏见。
2 to have a harmful effect on sb/sth 对…有不利影响: Continuing to live with her violent father may prejudice the child's welfare. 继续跟她暴烈的父亲生活在一起会对这孩子有害。

prejudiced
/ˈpredʒədɪst ||; ˈprɛdʒədɪst/adj not liking or trusting sb/sth for no other reason than his/her/its race, religion or sex 有偏见的；有成见的

preliminary¹
/prɪˈlɪmɪnəri; US -nerɪ ||; prɪˈlɪməˌnɛrɪ/adj coming or happening before sth else that is more important 预备的；初步的: After a few preliminary remarks the discussions began. 说了几句开场白之后，讨论正式开始。
preliminary²
/prɪˈlɪmɪnəri ||; prɪˈlɪməˌnɛrɪ/noun [C] [usu.pl] (plural preliminaries) an action or event that is done before and in preparation for another event 初步行动；准备工作: Once the preliminaries are over, we can get down to business. 准备工作完毕后，我们便可开始工作。

prelude
/ˈprelju:d ||; ˈprɛljud/noun[C]
1 a short piece of music, especially an introduction to a longer piece 前奏曲；序曲
2 (written 书面语)prelude (to sth) an action or event that happens before sth else or that forms an introduction to sth （某事的）前奏，序幕

premarital
/ˌpri:ˈmærɪtl ||; priˈmærətḷ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) existing or happening before marriage 婚前的: premarital sex 婚前性行为

premature
/ˈpremətʃə(r);ˌpreməˈtʃʊə(r); US ˌpri:məˈtʊər ||; ˌpriməˈtυr/adj
1 happening before the normal or expected time 比正常或预期时间早的；提前的；过早的: Her baby was premature (= born before the expected time). 她的婴儿早产了。
2 acting or happening too soon 不成熟的；草率的；仓促的: I think our decision was premature. We should have thought about it for longer. 我认为我们的决定过于仓促，应该多花一点时间考虑才对。 ➔prematurely adv

premeditated
/ˌpri:ˈmedɪteɪtɪd ||; prɪˈmɛdəˌtetɪd/adj (used about a crime) planned in advance （指罪行）预先计划的，预谋的

premenstrual
/ˌpri:ˈmenstruəl ||; priˈmɛnstruəl/adj happening or experienced before a woman loses blood each month (menstruation) 月经前的: Many women suffer from premenstrual syndrome, causing headaches and depression. 许多妇女患月经前综合症，会头疼和情绪低落。 ☞ Look at PMS⇒. 参看 PMS⇒。

premier¹
/ˈpremiə(r); US ˈpri:mɪər ||; ˈprimɪɚ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) most important; best 最重要的；首要的；最好的: a premier chef 厨师长 the Premier Division (= in football) 足球甲组联赛
premier²
/ˈpremiə(r) ||; ˈprimɪɚ/noun [C] (used especially in newspapers) the leader of the government of a country (prime minister) （尤用于报纸）总理，首相

premiere
/ˈpremieə(r); US pri:ˈmɪər;prɪˈmɪər ||; prɪˈmɪr; ɝɛḷɛTɛ/noun [C] the first public performance of a play, film, etc （戏剧、电影等的）首次公演，首映

premises
/ˈpremɪsɪz ||; ˈprɛmɪsɪz/noun [pl] the building and the land around it that a business owns or uses （企业、机构等拥有或使用的）建筑物及四周的地方: Smoking is not allowed on the premises. 场内不准吸烟。

premium
/ˈpri:miəm ||; ˈprimɪəm/noun[C]
1 an amount of money that you pay regularly to a company for insurance against accidents, damage, etc 保险费: a monthly premium of £25 每月25英镑的保险费
2 an extra payment 附加费；额外费用: You must pay a premium for express delivery. 如要使用快递服务，便得付额外费用。

premonition
/ˌpri:məˈnɪʃn;ˌprem- ||; ˌpriməˈnɪʃən; ˌprɛm-/noun [C] a premonition (of sth) a feeling that sth unpleasant is going to happen in the future （不祥的）预感，预兆: a premonition of disaster 预感灾难临头

prenatal
/ˌpri:ˈneɪtl ||; priˈnetḷ/adj (especially US 尤为美) =ANTENATAL ☞Compare post-natal. 与post-natal比较。

prenuptial agreement
/pri:ˌnʌpʃləˈgri:mənt ||; priˌnʌpʃəl əˈgrimənt/noun [C] (also informal 非正式 prenup /ˈpri:nʌp ||; ˈprinʌp/) an agreement made by a couple before they get married in which they say how their money and property should be divided if they get divorced 婚前协议﹙假如离婚财产如何分配﹚

preoccupation
/priˌɒkjuˈpeɪʃn ||; priˌɑkjəˈpeʃən/noun [U] [C] preoccupation (with sth) the state of thinking and/or worrying continuously about sth 全神贯注；专心；忧心忡忡: She was irritated by his preoccupation with money. 他老是想着钱，对此她很气恼。

preoccupied
/priˈɒkjupaɪd ||; priˈɑkjəˌpaɪd/adj preoccupied (with sth) not paying attention to sb/sth because you are thinking or worrying about sb/sth else 心不在焉的；全神贯注的；入神的: Sarah is very preoccupied with her work at present. 萨拉正在聚精会神地工作。 ☞Look at occupied. 参看occupied。

preoccupy
/priˈɒkjupaɪ ||; priˈɑkjəˌpaɪ/verb [T] (present participle preoccupying third person singular present preoccupies;past tense past participle preoccupied) to fill sb's mind so that he/she does not think about anything else; to worry 占据某人的思绪；使全神贯注或入神

ˌpre-ˈowned
adj (US 美) not new; owned by sb else before 旧的；二手的: pre-owned automobiles 二手汽车

prep
/prep ||; prɛp/verb [I,T] (prepping; prepped) (US, informal 美，非正式) to prepare (sth) 作好准备；预备: Prep the vegetables in advance. 事先准备好蔬菜。 They're prepping for college. 他们在为上大学作准备。

*preparation
/ˌprepəˈreɪʃn ||; ˌprɛpəˈreʃən/noun
1 [U] getting sb/sth ready 预备；准备: The team has been training hard in preparation for the big game. 该队在拚命训练，准备参加大赛。 exam preparation 考试前的准备
2 [C] [usu.pl] preparation (for sth/to do sth) something that you do to get ready for sth 筹备；筹划；预备工作: We started to make preparations for the wedding six months ago. 我们六个月前就开始为婚礼做准备工作。

preparatory
/prɪˈpærətri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; prɪˈpærəˌtɔrɪ/adj done in order to get ready for sth 预备的；准备的

preˈparatory school
(also prep school) noun [C]
1 (Brit 英) a private school for children aged between 7 and 13 预备学校（为7至13岁学童而设的私立学校）
2 (US 美) a private school that prepares students for college or university 预科学校（为准备上大学的学生而设的私立学校）

*prepare
/prɪˈpeə(r) ||; prɪˈpɛr/verb [I,T] prepare (sb/sth) (for sb/sth) to get ready or to make sb/sth ready 准备；预备；使做好准备；把…预备好: Bo helped me prepare for the exam. 博帮我准备考试。 The course prepares foreign students for studying at university. 这门课程帮助外国学生准备好进大学读书。 [T] to prepare a meal 做饭 be prepared for sth to be ready for sth difficult or unpleasant 对困难或不愉快的事情做好准备 be prepared to do sth to be ready and happy to do sth 准备、乐意做某事: I am not prepared to stay here and be insulted. 我不愿意待在这里受侮辱。

preponderance
/prɪˈpɒndərəns ||; prɪˈpɑndərəns/noun [sing] if there is a preponderance of one type of people or things in a group, there are more of them than others （数量上的）优势 [SYN] predominance 同义词为predominance

preponderant
/prɪˈpɒndərənt ||; prɪˈpɑndərənt/adj (formal 正式) (usually used before a noun 通常用于名词前) larger in number or more important than other people or things in a group 占多数的；占优势的

preposition
/ˌprepəˈzɪʃn ||; ˌprɛpəˈzɪʃən/noun [C] (grammar语法) a word or phrase that is used before a noun or pronoun to show place, time, direction, etc 介词（用于名词或代名词前的单词或词组，表示地方、时间、方向等）: ‘In’, ‘for’, ‘to’ and ‘out of’ are all prepositions. in、for、to和out of都是介词。

preposterous
/prɪˈpɒstərəs ||; prɪˈpɑstərəs/adj silly; ridiculous; not to be taken seriously 愚蠢的；荒谬的；不象话的

prequel
/pri:kwəl ||; ˈprikwəl/noun [C] a book or a film/movie about events that happened before those in a popular book or film/movie 先篇；前篇；前传: Fans waited for years for a prequel to Star Wars. 影迷们翘首以待《星球大战》的前传已有多年了。 ☞ Compare sequel. 与 sequel 比较。

ˌpre-reˈcorded
adj (used about a piece of music, a film, radio or TV programme) that has been recorded in advance so that it can be played later ﹙乐曲、影片、节目等﹚预先录制的，预录的: a pre-recorded interview 预先录制好的采访节目

prerequisite
/ˌpri:ˈrekwəzɪt ||; priˈrɛkwəzɪt/noun [C] a prerequisite (for/of sth) something that is necessary for sth to happen or exist 先决条件；必备条件: Is a good education a prerequisite of success? 良好的教育是不是成功的先决条件呢？

prerogative
/prɪˈrɒgətɪv ||; prɪˈrɑgətɪv/noun [C] a special right that sb/sth has 特权: It is the Prime Minister's prerogative to fix the date of the election. 确定大选日期是首相的特权。

Pres.
abbr President 总统；主席

prescribe
/prɪˈskraɪb ||; prɪˈskraɪb/verb[T]
1 to say what medicine or treatment sb should have 开药（方）；处方: Can you prescribe something for my cough please, doctor? 医生，请你给我开一些咳嗽药，可以吗？
2 (formal 正式) (used about a person or an organization with authority) to say that sth must be done （指有权力的人或机构）规定，指定: The law prescribes that the document must be signed in the presence of two witnesses. 法律规定这份文件必须在有两名见证人在场的情况下签署。

prescription
/prɪˈskrɪpʃn ||; prɪˈskrɪpʃən/noun [C,U] a paper on which a doctor has written the name of the medicine that you need. You take your prescription to the CHEMIST'S and get the medicine there. 药方；处方: a prescription for sleeping pills 安眠药处方 Some medicines are only available on prescription (= with a prescription from a doctor). 有些药物只有凭医生的处方才买得到。

presence
/ˈprezns ||; ˈprɛzṇs/noun
1 [U] the fact of being in a particular place 出席；在场: He apologized to her in the presence of the whole family. 他当着全家人的面向她道歉。 an experiment to test for the presence of oxygen 一项测试是否含氧的实验 [OPP] absence 反义词为absence
2 [sing] a number of soldiers or police officers who are in a place for a special reason （为执行某种职务而在场的）士兵或警察: There was a huge police presence at the demonstration. 示威进行期间有大批警察在场戒备。

*present¹
/ˈpreznt ||; ˈprɛzṇt/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) existing or happening now 现存的；现在的；目前的: We hope to overcome our present difficulties very soon. 我们希望很快就能克服目前的困难。
2 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) being in a particular place 在场；出席: There were 200 people present at the meeting. 有200人出席这个会议。 [OPP] absent 反义词为absent
the present day modern times 现代；当代；当今: In some countries traditional methods of farming have survived to the present day. 在一些国家，传统的耕种方法沿用至今。
*present²
/ˈpreznt ||; ˈprɛzṇt/noun
1 [C] something that you give to sb or receive from sb 礼物；赠品: a birthday/wedding/leaving/Christmas present 生日╱结婚╱送别╱圣诞节礼物 ☞ Gift is more formal and is often used in shops, catalogues, etc. gift用于较正式的场合，常用于商店、目录等。
2 usuallythe present [sing] the time now 现在；目前: We live in the present but we must learn from the past. 我们虽然生活在现代，但必须从过去中学习。 I'm rather busy at present. Can I call you back later? 我现在很忙，待会儿给你回电话好吗？
3 the present [sing] = THE PRESENT TENSE
for the moment/present→MOMENT
present³
/prɪˈzent ||; prɪˈzɛnt/verb[T]
1 present sb with sth;present sth (to sb) to give sth to sb, especially at a formal ceremony 给予，赠送（尤指在正式仪式上授予、呈献）: All the dancers were presented with flowers. 所有舞蹈演员都有人给他们献花。 Flowers were presented to all the dancers. 鲜花献给了所有舞蹈演员。
2 present sth (to sb) to show sth that you have prepared to people 显示；提出: Good teachers try to present their material in an interesting way. 好的教师会设法以有趣的方式讲课。
3 present sb with sth;present sth (to sb) to give sb sth that has to be dealt with 提供，提交，引起（问题）: Learning English presented no problem to him. 学习英语对他不成问题。 The manager presented us with a bill for the broken chair. 有把椅子给我们弄坏了，经理给我们开了一张索赔账单。
4 to introduce a television or radio programme 推出（电视或电台节目）
5 to show a play, etc to the public 公演；演出；上演: The Theatre Royal is presenting a new production of ‘Ghosts’. 皇家剧院正公演全新制作的《鬼魂》。
6 present sb (to sb) to introduce sb to a person in a formal ceremony （在正式场合）介绍，引见（某人）: The teams were presented to the President before the game. 比赛开始之前，两支球队获引见给总统。

presentable
/prɪˈzentəbl ||; prɪˈzɛntəbḷ/adj good enough to be seen by people you do not know well 象样的；体面的；拿得出去的

presentation
/ˌpreznˈteɪʃn; US ˌpri:zen- ||; ˌprizɛnˈteʃən/noun
1 [C,U] the act of giving or showing sth to sb 赠送；授予；呈献；显示: The head will now make a presentation to the winners of the competition. 现在，领导将向比赛的优胜者颁奖。
2 [U] the way in which sth is shown, explained, offered, etc to people 显示、解释或提供的方式: Untidy presentation of your work may lose you marks. 作业写得杂乱无章可能会使你被扣分。
3 [C] a meeting at which sth, especially a new product or idea, or piece of work, is shown or explained to a group of people 研讨；陈述；发表: Each student has to give a short presentationon a subject of his/her choice. 每个学生都要就某个自选题目作简短的报告。
4 [C] a formal ceremony at which a prize, etc is given to sb 颁奖仪式；颁授典礼

presenter
/prɪˈzentə(r) ||; prɪˈzɛntɚ/noun [C] a person who introduces a television or radio programme （电视或电台节目）主持人

presently
/ˈprezntli ||; ˈprɛzṇtlɪ/adv
1 soon; shortly 不久；马上: I'll be finished presently. 我马上就要完成。
2 (written 书面语) after a short time 在短时间之后；过了一会儿；不久: Presently I heard the car door shut. 过了一会儿，我听见车门关上的声音。
3 (especially US 尤为美) now; currently 现在；目前: The management are presently discussing the matter. 管理当局现在正讨论这件事。 ☞Notice that when presently means ‘soon’ it usually comes at the end of the sentence and when it means ‘after a short time’ it usually comes at the beginning of the sentence. When presently means ‘now’ it goes with the verb. 注意，presently指“马上”时，通常在句末出现；presently指“不久”时，通常在句首出现。presently指“现在”时，则与动词连用。

ˌpresent ˈparticiple
noun [C] (grammar语法) the form of the verb that ends in -ing 现在分词（以-ing结尾的动词形式）

preservative
/prɪˈzɜ:vətɪv ||; prɪˈzɝvətɪv/noun [C,U] a substance that is used for keeping food, etc in good condition （食物的）防腐剂

*preserve
/prɪˈzɜ:v ||; prɪˈzɝv/verb [T] to keep sth safe or in good condition 保护；维持；保养；保存: They've managed to preserve most of the wall paintings in the caves. 他们设法保存了那些洞穴内的大部份壁画。 ➔preservation /ˌprezəˈveɪʃn ||; ˌprɛzɚˈveʃən/ noun [U]

preset
/ˌpri:ˈset ||; ˌpriˈsɛt/ (also pre-set) verb [T] (present participle presetting; past tense, past participle preset) to set the controls of a piece of electrical equipment so that it will start to work at a particular time 预先设置；预调: to preset TV channels/radio stations (= to set the controls so that particular channels are selected when you press particular buttons)预调电视频道/广播电台 The water is heated to a preset temperature. 水温加热至默认温度。 ➔preset noun [C]

preside
/prɪˈzaɪd ||; prɪˈzaɪd/verb [I] to be in charge of a discussion, meeting, etc 主持（讨论、会议等） preside over sth to be in control of or responsible for sth 掌管；主管；负责

presidency
/ˈprezɪdənsi ||; ˈprɛzədənsɪ/noun (plural presidencies)
1 the presidency [sing] the position of being president 总统或主席等的职位
2 [C] the period of time that sb is president 总统或主席等的任期；担任总统或主席等的期间

*president
/ˈprezɪdənt ||; ˈprɛzədənt/noun[C]
1 (also President) the leader of a republic 总统: the President of France 法国总统 the US President 美国总统
2 the person with the highest position in some organizations 总裁；董事长 ➔presidential /ˌprezɪˈdenʃl ||; ˌprɛzəˈdɛnʃəl/ adj presidential elections 总统选举

*press¹
/pres ||; prɛs/noun
1 usuallythe press [sing] [with.sop] newspapers and the journalists who work for them 报界；新闻界: The story has been reported on TV and in the press. 电视和报界已对这则消息作了报道。 the local/national press 本地╱全国新闻界 The press support/supports government policy. 新闻界支持政府的政策。
2 [sing] [U] what or the amount that is written about sb/sth in newspapers （报纸对某人或某事的）评论，报道量: This company has had a bad press recently. 该公司最近受到新闻界的恶评。 The strike got very little press. 报纸极少报道罢工的事。
3 [C,U] a machine for printing books, newspapers, etc; the process of printing them 印刷机；（书、报等的）印刷: All details were correct at the time of going to press. 付印的时候所有细节都正确无误。
4 [C] a business that prints books, etc 出版社: Oxford University Press 牛津大学出版社
5 [C] an act of pushing sth firmly （用力的）压，推，挤，按: Give that button a pressand see what happens. 单击那个按钮，看看会怎么样。
*press²
/pres ||; prɛs/verb
1 [I,T] to push sth firmly （用力）压，推，挤，按: Just press that button and the door will open. 只须按那个按钮，门就会开。 He pressed the lid firmly shut. 他把盖子紧紧地按住。
2 [T] to put weight onto sth, for example in order to get juice out of it 挤压，榨取（如果汁）: to press grapes 压榨葡萄 ☞picture at squeeze 见squeeze插图
3 [T] to make a piece of clothing smooth by using an iron （用熨斗）熨平: This shirt needs pressing. 这件衬衫需要熨一熨。
4 [T] to hold sb/sth firmly in a loving way （关爱地）紧握，紧抱: She pressed the photo to her chest. 她把那张照片搂在怀里。
5 [I] press across, against, around, etc (sth) (used about people) to move in a particular direction by pushing （指人）推挤着朝某方向前进: The crowd pressed against the wall of policemen. 人群挤向警察筑成的人墙。
6 [I,T] press (sb) (for sth/to do sth) to try to persuade or force sb to do sth 试图劝说或强迫某人做某事: I pressed them to stay for dinner. 我力劝他们留下吃晚饭。 to press sb for an answer 催促某人答复
7 [T] to express or repeat sth in an urgent way 迫切表达或重复；强调: I don't want to press the point, but you still owe me money. 我不想强调这一点，但你还欠我钱。
be hard pressed/pushed/put to do sth→HARD² be pressed for sth to not have enough of sth 缺少；缺乏: I must hurry. I'm really pressed for time. 我得赶快去，时间实在紧迫。 bring/press charges (against sb)→CHARGE¹ press ahead/forward/on (with sth) to continue doing sth even though it is difficult or hard work （虽然困难或艰辛仍）继续或坚持做: They pressed on with the building work in spite of the bad weather. 虽然天气恶劣，他们仍然继续进行建筑工程。

ˈpress conference
noun [C] a meeting when a famous or important person answers questions from newspaper and television journalists 记者招待会: to hold a press conference 举行记者招待会

pressing
/ˈpresɪŋ ||; ˈprɛsɪŋ/adj that must be dealt with immediately; urgent 紧迫的；急迫的；必须立刻处理的

ˈpress release
noun [C] an official statement made to journalists by a large organization, a political party or a government department ﹙向媒体发布的﹚新闻稿: The company issued a press release to end speculation about its future. 公司发布了新闻稿，以阻止人们对公司未来的猜测。

ˈpress secretary
noun [C] person who works for a politician or a political organization and gives information about them to journalists, the newspapers, etc 新闻秘书

ˈpress stud
noun [C] =POPPER

ˈpress-up
(US 美 push-up) noun [C] a type of exercise in which you lie on your front on the floor and push your body up with your arms 俯卧撑；掌上压；伏地挺身: I do 50 press-ups every morning. 我每天早上做50下俯卧撑。 ☞picture at sport 见Ｓ２插图

*pressure
/ˈpreʃə(r) ||; ˈprɛʃɚ/noun
1 [U] the force that is produced when you press on or against sth （压、推、挤或按产生的）压力；压强: Apply pressure to the cut and it will stop bleeding. 用力按着伤口便能止血。 The pressure of the water caused the dam to crack. 水的压力引致堤坝破裂。
2 [C,U] the force that a gas or liquid has when it is contained inside sth （气体或液体形成的）压力: high/low blood pressure 高╱低血压 You should check your tyre pressures regularly. 你应定期检查轮胎气压。
3 [C,U] worries or difficulties that you have because you have too much to deal with; stress （担心或困难造成的）压力: financial pressures 财政压力 I find it difficult to cope with pressure at work. 我觉得难以应付工作压力。
put pressure on sb (to do sth) to force sb to do sth 强迫某人（做某事）；向某人施加压力: The press is putting pressure on him to resign. 新闻界正向他施加压力，逼他辞职。 under pressure
1 being forced to do sth 被逼（做某事）: Anna was under pressure from her parents to leave school and get a job. 安娜受到父母的压力，要她辍学找事做。
2 worried or in difficulty because you have too much to deal with （因要处理很多事情而）担心，处境困难，有压力: I perform poorly under pressure, so I hate exams. 我在有压力的情况下总是考不好，因此我讨厌考试。
3 (used about liquid or gas) contained inside sth or sent somewhere using force （指某物内的液体或气体）在压力下: Water is forced out through the hose under pressure. 水在压力下被从那软管里压了出来。 pressure verb [T] =PRESSURIZE

ˈpressure cooker
noun [C] a strong metal pot with a tight lid, that cooks food quickly using steam under high pressure 高压锅；压力锅 ☞picture at pan 见pan插图

ˈpressure group
noun [C] [with.sop] a group of people who are trying to influence what a government or other organization does 压力团体（试图影响政府或其他机构的一组人）

pressurize
/ˈpreʃəraɪz ||; ˈprɛʃəˌraɪz/ (also -ise) (also pressure) verb [T] pressurize sb (into sth/doing sth) to use force or influence to make sb do sth 利用武力或影响力使某人做某事: Some workers were pressurized into taking early retirement. 有些工人被迫提早退休。

pressurized
/ˈpreʃəraɪzd ||; ˈprɛʃəˌraɪzd/ (also -ised) adj (used about air in an aircraft) kept at the pressure at which people can breathe （指机舱里的空气）增压的（使人可以呼吸）

prestige
/preˈsti:ʒ ||; prɛsˈtiʒ/noun [U] the respect and admiration that people feel for a person because he/she has a high social position or has been very successful 威望；声望；威信: Nursing isn't a high prestige job. 护理并不是很令人羡慕的工作。 ➔prestigious /preˈstɪdʒəs ||; prɛˈstɪdʒəs/ adj a prestigious prize/school/job 享有盛名的奖╱学校╱工作

presumably
/prɪˈzju:məbli ||; prɪˈzjuməblɪ/adv I imagine; I suppose 据推测；大概: Presumably this rain means the match will be cancelled? 下了这场雨大概比赛要取消了吧？

presume
/prɪˈzju:m ||; prɪˈzjum/verb [T] to think that sth is true even if you do not know for sure; to suppose 推测；假设；假定: The house looks empty so I presume they are away on holiday. 房子看来空无一人，因此我推测他们度假去了。 ➔presumption /prɪˈzʌmpʃn ||; prɪˈzʌmpʃən/ noun [C]

presumptuous
/prɪˈzʌmptʃuəs ||; prɪˈzʌmptʃυəs/adj confident that sth will happen or that sb will do sth without making sure first, in a way that annoys people 放肆的；专横的；自以为是的: It was very presumptuous of him to say that I would help without asking me first. 他实在太自作主张了，竟然没有先问问我便说我会帮忙。

presuppose
