/ˌpri:səˈpəʊz ||; ˌprisəˈpoz/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to accept sth as true or existing and act on that basis, before it has been shown to be true 推测；预想: Teachers sometimes presuppose a fairly high level of knowledge by the students. 老师有时对学生的知识面估计颇高。 [SYN] presume 同义词为presume
2 to depend on sth in order to exist or be true 以…为前提或先决条件: His argument presupposes that it does not matter who is in power. 他的论点以无论谁掌权都无关系为前提。

ˌpre-ˈtax
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) before the tax has been taken away 未扣税的；税前的: pre-tax profits/losses/income 税前利润/亏损/收入

pre-teen
/ˌpri:ˈti:n ||; ˌpriˈtin/adj used about a boy or girl just under the age of thirteen 十一、二岁的: pre-teen girls 十一、二岁的女孩 ➔preteen noun [C]

pretence
/prɪˈtens ||; prɪˈtɛns/ (US 美 pretense) noun [U] [sing] an action that makes people believe sth that is not true 假装；矫饰；虚伪 [sing] She was unable to keep up the pretence that she loved him. 她无法再假装自己爱他。 on/under false pretences→FALSE

*pretend
/prɪˈtend ||; prɪˈtɛnd/verb[I,T]
1 to behave in a particular way in order to make other people believe sth that is not true 假装；伪装；装作: You can't just pretend that the problem doesn't exist. 你不能就装作问题并不存在。 Paul's not really asleep. He's just pretending. 保罗不是真的睡着了，只是装睡而已。
2 (used especially about children) to imagine that sth is true as part of a game （尤指孩子）扮，装扮: The kids were under the bed pretending to be snakes. 孩子们钻进床底下，扮作蛇。

pretentious
/prɪˈtenʃəs ||; prɪˈtɛnʃəs/adj trying to appear more serious or important than you really are 自命不凡的；自抬身价的；狂妄的: I think it sounds pretentious to use a lot of foreign words. 我认为，使用很多外国词听上去就有点自命不凡。

pretest
/ˌpri:ˈtest ||; ˌpriˈtɛst/noun [C] a test that you take to find out how much you already know or can do before learning or doing sth ﹙学习前或事前的﹚测试 ➔pretest verb [T]

pretext
/ˈpri:tekst ||; ˈpritɛkst/noun [C] a reason that you give for doing sth that is not the real reason 借口；托词: Tariq left on the pretext of having an appointment at the dentist's. 塔里克以约了牙医看病为借口离去。

*pretty¹
/ˈprɪti ||; ˈprɪtɪ/adj (prettier;prettiest) attractive and pleasant to look at or hear 漂亮；标致；俊俏: a pretty girl/smile/dress/garden/name 漂亮的姑娘；动人的微笑；漂亮的连衣裙；漂亮的花园；漂亮的名字 ☞ Pretty is not normally used to describe men or boys. Good-looking can be used for all people, and handsome is usually used for men. Look also at the note at beautiful. pretty一般不用于形容男子或男孩子。Good-looking可用于形容所有人；handsome通常用来形容男子。另参看beautiful的注释。 ➔prettily adv The room is prettily decorated. 这房间布置得很漂亮。 ➔prettiness noun [U]
*pretty²
/ˈprɪti ||; ˈprɪtɪ/adv (informal 非正式) quite; fairly 很；相当: The film was pretty good but not fantastic. 那部电影相当不错，但不算很棒。 I'm pretty certain that Alex will agree. 我相当肯定亚历克斯会同意。 ☞Look at the note at rather. 参看rather的注释。 pretty much/nearly/well almost; very nearly 差不多；几乎: I won't be long. I've pretty well finished. 我不会花太长时间，我差不多完成了。

prevail
/prɪˈveɪl ||; prɪˈvel/verb[I]
1 to exist or be common in a particular place or at a particular time 存在；流行；盛行: In some remote areas traditional methods of farming still prevail. 在一些偏远地区，传统的耕作方法仍然盛行。
2 (formal 正式)prevail (against/over sb/sth) to win or be accepted, especially after a fight or discussion （尤指经过争吵或讨论之后）获胜，被接受: In the end justice prevailed and the men were set free. 最后，正义得以伸张，那几个男子获得释放。

prevailing
/prɪˈveɪlɪŋ ||; prɪˈvelɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前)
1 existing or most common at a particular time （在某个时候）流行，盛行，普遍: the prevailing climate of opinion 流行的舆论气氛
2 (used about the wind) most common in a particular area （指风在某个地区）常刮的: The prevailing wind is from the south-west. 风常从西南面吹来。

prevalent
/ˈprevələnt ||; ˈprɛvələnt/adj (formal 正式) most common in a particular place at a particular time （在某时某地）流行的，盛行的，普遍的: The prevalent atmosphere was one of fear. 当时的气氛人心惶惶。 ➔prevalence /-əns ||; -əns/ noun [U]

*prevent
/prɪˈvent ||; prɪˈvɛnt/verb [T] prevent sb/sth (from) (doing sth) to stop sth happening or to stop sb doing sth 防止；预防；阻止；制止: This accident could have been prevented. 这起事故本来是可以防止的。 Her parents tried to prevent her from going to live with her boyfriend. 她的父母设法阻止她与男朋友同居。 ☞ Prevent is more formal than stop. 与stop相比，prevent多用于正式场合。 ➔prevention noun [U]: accident/crime prevention 预防事故╱犯罪

preventable
/prɪˈventəbl ||; prɪˈvɛntəbḷ/adj that can be prevented 可防止的；可预防的: Many accidents are preventable. 很多意外是可以预防的。

preventive
/prɪˈventɪv ||; prɪˈvɛntɪv/ (also preventative /prɪˈventətɪv ||; prɪˈvɛntətɪv/) adj intended to stop or prevent sth from happening 预防的；防止的: preventative medicine 预防医学

preview
/ˈpri:vju: ||; ˈpriˌvju/noun [C] a chance to see a play, film, etc before it is shown to the general public （戏剧、电影等的）试演，预映

*previous
/ˈpri:viəs ||; ˈprivɪəs/adj coming or happening before or earlier 以前的；先前的: Do you have previous experience of this type of work? 你以前做过这种工作吗？ ➔previously adv Before I moved to Spain I had previously worked in Italy. 我移居西班牙前，曾经在意大利工作。

prey¹
/preɪ ||; pre/noun [U] an animal or bird that is killed and eaten by another animal or bird 被捕食的鸟兽；猎物: The eagle is a bird of prey (= it kills and eats other birds or small animals). 鹰是一种食肉猛禽（捕食其他鸟类及小动物）。
prey²
/preɪ ||; pre/verb prey on sb's mind to cause sb to worry or think about sth 使忧虑；使困扰: The thought that he was responsible for the accident preyed on the train driver's mind. 火车司机认为意外事件自己有责，内心终日惴惴不安。 prey on sth (used about an animal or bird) to kill and eat other animals or birds （指动物或鸟类）捕食: Owls prey on mice and other small animals. 猫头鹰捕食老鼠和其他小动物。

*price¹
/praɪs ||; praɪs/noun
1 [C] the amount of money that you must pay in order to buy sth 价格；价钱: What's the price of petrol now? 现在汽油的价格是多少？ We can't afford to buy the car at that price. 以那个价格，我们买不起这辆车。 There's no price on (= written on) this jar of coffee. 这罐咖啡没有标价。 ☞A charge is the amount of money that you must pay for using something Is there a charge for parking here? admission charges. You use cost when you are talking about paying for services or about prices in general without mentioning an actual sum of money The cost of electricity is going up. the cost of living. The price of something is the amount of money that you must pay in order to buy it. A shop may raise / increase, reduce / bring down or freeze its prices. The prices rise / go up or fall / go down. charge指使用某物要付的金额：Is there a charge for parking here?在这里停放车辆须要缴费吗？·admission charge入场费。cost是指服务的收费或一般的价钱，并且未提确切金额：The cost of electricity is going up.电费在上涨。·the cost of living生活费用。price是指购物时所要付的金额。商店可以提高(raise／increase)、降低(reduce／bring down)或冻结(freeze)价格。价格可以上涨(rise／go up)或下跌(fall／go down)。
2 [sing] unpleasant things that you have to experience in order to achieve sth or as a result of sth 代价: Sleepless nights are a small price to pay for having a baby. 不眠之夜是为生养婴儿所付出的小小代价。
at a price costing a lot of money or involving sth unpleasant 以高价；以很高代价: He'll help you get a job -- at a price. 他会帮你找个工作─但是代价很高。 at any price even if the cost is very high or if it will have unpleasant results 不惜任何代价；无论如何: Richard was determined to succeed at any price. 理查德德决心不惜任何代价争取成功。 not at any price never; under no circumstances 绝不；永不
price²
/praɪs ||; praɪs/verb [T] to fix the price of sth or to write the price on sth 给某物定价或标价: The books were all priced at between £5 and £10. 那些书籍定价在5至10英镑之间。

priceless
/ˈpraɪsləs ||; ˈpraɪsləs/adj of very great value 无价的；十分贵重的: priceless jewels and antiques 贵重的珠宝和古董 ☞Look at worthless, valuable and invaluable. 参看worthless、valuable及invaluable。

ˈprice list
noun [C] a list of the prices of the goods that are on sale 价目表；价目单

ˈprice tag
noun [C] a label on sth that shows how much you must pay 价格标签: (figurative 比喻)The new quarterback comes with a price tag of $2 million. 新来的四分卫身价200万元。

pricey
/ˈpraɪsi ||; ˈpraɪsɪ/adj (informal 非正式) expensive 昂贵的

prick¹
/prɪk ||; prɪk/verb [T] to make a small hole in sth or to cause sb pain with a sharp point 在（某物）上扎孔；（用尖物）刺痛（某人）: She pricked her finger on a needle. 她的手指给针扎到了。 prick up your ears (used about an animal) to hold up the ears in order to listen carefully to sth （指动物）竖起耳朵仔细听 (figurative 比喻) Mike pricked up his ears when he heard Emma's name mentioned. 迈克一听到埃玛的名字便立刻注意起来。
prick²
/prɪk ||; prɪk/noun [C] the sudden pain that you feel when sth sharp goes into your skin 刺痛

prickle¹
/ˈprɪkl ||; ˈprɪkḷ/noun [C] one of the sharp points on some plants and animals （植物或动物的）棘，尖刺: Hedgehogs are covered in prickles. 刺猬身上长满尖刺。 ☞Look at spine. 参看spine。 ☞picture at hedgehog 见hedgehog插图
prickle²
/ˈprɪkl ||; ˈprɪkḷ/verb [I] to have or make sb/sth have an uncomfortable feeling on the skin （使）感到刺痛: I don't like that shirt -- it prickles. 我不喜欢那件衬衫─穿着扎痛人。 His skin prickled with fear. 他恐惧得皮肤感到刺痛。

prickly
/ˈprɪkli ||; ˈprɪklɪ/adj
1 covered with sharp points 满布针刺的；多刺的: a prickly bush 一簇多刺的灌木
2 causing an uncomfortable feeling on the skin 刺痛的；扎痛人的: That T-shirt makes my skin go all prickly. 穿着那件T恤衫我浑身皮肤发痒。
3 (informal 非正式) (used about a person) easily made angry （指人）易怒的，脾气暴躁的: Don't mention his accident -- he's a bit prickly about it. 别提起那宗事故─他对此有点敏感。

*pride¹
/praɪd ||; praɪd/noun
1 [U] [sing] pride (in sth/doing sth) the feeling of pleasure that you have when you or people who are close to you do sth good or own sth good 自豪；得意: I take a great pridein my work. 我为自己的工作感到十分自豪。 Her parents watched with pride as Milena went up to collect her prize. 米丽娜的父母自豪地看着她上台领奖。 You should feel pride in your achievement. 你应该为自己的成就感到自豪。
2 [U] the respect that you have for yourself 自尊（心）: You'll hurt his pride if you refuse to accept the present. 如果你拒绝接受礼物，便会伤害他的自尊心。
3 [U] the feeling that you are better than other people 骄傲；自大；自负
4 [sing] the pride of sth/sb a person or thing that is very important or of great value to sth/sb 引以为荣的人或事物: The new stadium was the pride of the whole town. 这座新体育场使全城的人都感到自豪。 ☞adjective proud 形容词为proud
sb's pride and joy a thing or person that gives sb great pleasure or satisfaction 给某人快乐、满足的事物或人
pride²
/praɪd ||; praɪd/verb pride yourself on sth/doing sth to feel pleased about sth good or clever that you can do 以…自豪；对…感到得意: Fabio prides himself on his ability to cook. 法比奥对自己的烹饪技巧感到自豪。

*priest
/pri:st ||; prist/noun [C] a person who performs religious ceremonies in some religions 神父；牧师；教士 ☞In some religions a female priest is called a priestess. 某些宗教里的女神职人员叫做priestess。

prim
/prɪm ||; prɪm/adj (used about a person) always behaving in a careful or formal way and easily shocked by anything that is rude （指人）一本正经的，拘谨的，古板的 ➔primly adv

primarily
/ˈpraɪmərəli;praɪˈmerəli; US praɪˈmerəlɪ ||; praɪˈmɛrəlɪ/adv more than anything else; mainly 首要；主要: The course is aimed primarily at beginners. 本课程主要针对初学者。

*primary¹
/ˈpraɪməri; US -merɪ ||; ˈpraɪˌmɛrɪ/adj
1 most important; main 最重要的；首要的；主要的: Smoking is one of the primary causes of lung cancer. 吸烟是引起肺癌的主要原因之一。
2 connected with the education of children between about five and eleven years old 与五至十一岁的儿童教育有关的；初等教育的；小学的: Their children are at primary school. 他们的孩子在上小学。
primary²
/ˈpraɪməri; US -merɪ ||; ˈpraɪˌmɛrɪ/ (also primary eˈlection) noun [C] (plural primaries) (US 美) an election in which people from a particular area vote to choose a CANDIDATE (= a person who will represent the party) for a future important election 初选（政党通过初选选出党内候选人参与重要公职选举）

ˌprimary ˈcolour
noun [C] any of the colours red, yellow or blue. You can make any other colour by mixing primary colours in different ways. 原色，基色（即红、黄、蓝三色之一）

primate
/ˈpraɪmeɪt ||; ˈpraɪmet/noun [C] any animal that belongs to the group that includes humans, monkeys and animals like monkeys without a tail(apes) 灵长目动物（包括人类、猴子及无尾猿）

prime¹
/praɪm ||; praɪm/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前)
1 main; the first example of sth that sb would think of or choose 主要的；首要的: She is a prime candidate as the next team captain. 她是下任队长的主要候选人。
2 of very good quality; best 优质的；最好的；上等的: prime pieces of beef 上等牛肉
3 having all the typical qualities 最典型的；最具代表性的: That's a prime example of what I was talking about. 那是我刚才所说之事的典型例子。
prime²
/praɪm ||; praɪm/noun [sing] the time when sb is strongest, most beautiful, most successful, etc 壮年；最美好的岁月；颠峰时期: Several of the team are past their prime. 该队有几名成员已经过了颠峰时期。 In his prime, he was a fine actor. 他在盛年时曾是一名出色的演员。 to be in the prime of life 正值盛年
prime³
/praɪm ||; praɪm/verb [T] prime sb (for/with sth) to give sb information in order to prepare him/her for sth 事先提供数据使作好准备: The politician had been well primed with all the facts before the interview. 那位政治家在接受采访前已充分掌握一切有关资料。

ˌprime ˈminister
noun [C] (abbr PM) the leader of the government in some countries, for example Britain （英国等的）首相，总理 ☞Look at minister. 参看minister。

ˌprime ˈnumber
noun [C] (mathematics数学) a number that can be divided exactly only by itself and 1, for example 7, 17 and 41 素数﹙即只能被１除尽的数﹐如７﹑１７及４７﹚

primer
noun
1 /ˈpraɪmə(r) ||; ˈpraɪmɚ/ [C,U] a type of paint that is put on wood, metal, etc before it is painted to help the paint to stay on the surface 底漆；底层涂料
2 /ˈpraɪmə(r) ||; ˈprɪmɚ/ [C] (US 美) a book that contains basic instructions, explanations, etc 初级读本；入门书: The President doesn't need a primer on national security. 总统对于国家安全事务是不需要读入门书的。

primeval
/praɪˈmi:vl ||; praɪˈmivḷ/ (also primaeval) adj from the earliest period of the history of the world, very ancient 原始的；远古的

primitive
/ˈprɪmətɪv ||; ˈprɪmətɪv/adj
1 very simple and not developed 简单的；简陋的；原始的: The washing facilities in the camp were very primitive. 营地的洗涤设施十分简陋。
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with a very early stage in the development of humans or animals （人类或动物的发展阶段）原始的，早期的: Primitive man lived in caves and hunted wild animals. 原始人居住在洞穴里，以捕猎野兽为生。

primrose
/ˈprɪmrəʊz ||; ˈprɪmˌroz/noun [C] a yellow spring flower 报春花 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图

*prince
/prɪns ||; prɪns/noun[C]
1 a son or other close male relative of a king or queen 王子；亲王；王孙；国王或女王的男性近亲
2 the male ruler of a small country （小国的）君主，国君

*princess
/ˌprɪnˈses ||; ˈprɪnsɪs/noun[C]
1 a daughter or other close female relative of a king or queen 公主；孙公主；国王或女王的女性近亲
2 the wife of a prince 王妃

*principal¹
/ˈprɪnsəpl ||; ˈprɪnsəpḷ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) most important; main 最重要的；首要的；主要的: the principal characters in a play 戏剧里的主要角色 ➔principally /-pli ||; -plɪ/ adv Our products are designed principally for the European market. 我们的产品主要为欧洲市场设计。
principal²
/ˈprɪnsəpl ||; ˈprɪnsəpḷ/noun [C] the head of some schools, colleges, etc 校长；院长

*principle
/ˈprɪnsəpl ||; ˈprɪnsəpḷ/noun
1 [C,U] a rule for good behaviour, based on what a person believes is right 原则；行为准则: He doesn't eat meat on principle. 他依照原则不吃肉。 She refuses to wear fur. It's a matter of principle with her. 她拒绝穿毛皮，对她来说，那是个原则问题。
2 [C] a basic general law, rule or idea 原理；定律: The system works on the principle that heat rises. 那系统根据热空气上升的原理运作。 The course teaches the basic principles of car maintenance. 这门课程教授汽车保养的基本原理。
in principle in general, but possibly not in detail 基本上；大体上: His proposal sounds fine in principle, but there are a few points I'm not happy about. 他的建议听起来大体上不错，但有几点我不太满意。

*print¹
/prɪnt ||; prɪnt/verb
1 [I,T] to put words, pictures, etc onto paper by using a special machine 印；印刷；印制: How much did it cost to print the posters? 印制这些海报要花多少钱？
2 [T] to produce books, newspapers, etc in this way 印制（书籍、报纸等） · 50000 copies of the textbook were printed. 那本教科书已印了50000册。
3 [T] to include sth in a book, newspaper, etc 刊载于，印于（书籍、报纸等）: The newspaper should not have printed the photographs of the crash. 那份报纸不该刊载那宗事故的照片。
4 [T] to make a photograph from a piece of negative film （由底片）冲印照片
5 [I,T] to write with letters that are not joined together 用印刷体书写: Please print your name clearly at the top of the paper. 请在纸的上端用印刷体写上名字。
6 [T] to put a pattern onto cloth, paper, etc （在布、纸等上）印图案 ➔printing noun [U]
print (sth) out to print information from a computer onto paper （用计算机）打印: I'll just print out this file. 我会把这个文件打印出来。
*print²
/prɪnt ||; prɪnt/noun
1 [U] the letters, words, etc in a book, newspaper, etc 印出的字；印刷字体: The print is too small for me to read without my glasses. 这字体太小，我不戴眼镜就看不清。
2 [U] used to refer to the business of producing newspapers, books, etc 印刷业: the print unions/workers 印刷工会╱工人
3 [C] a mark that is made by sth pressing onto sth else 印痕；印记: The police are searching the room for fingerprints. 警方正在房间里搜寻指纹。 footprints in the snow 雪地上的脚印
4 [C] a picture that was made by printing （印出来的）图片，图画
5 [C] a photograph (when it has been printed from a negative) （由底片冲印出的）照片，相片: I ordered an extra set of prints for my friends. 我多冲印了一套照片送给朋友。
in print
1 (used about a book) still available from the company that published it （指书）仍可买到的，仍在出售的
2 (used about a person's work) published in a book, newspaper, etc （指作品）已出版的，已发表的
out of print (used about a book) no longer available from the company that published it; not being printed any more （指书）售完的，绝版的

printer
/ˈprɪntə(r) ||; ˈprɪntɚ/noun[C]
1 a person or company that prints books, newspapers, etc 印刷业者；印刷商；印刷公司
2 a machine that prints out information from a computer onto paper （计算机的）打印机: a laser printer 激光打印机 ☞picture on page S2 见S2页插图

ˈprinting press
(also press) noun [C] a machine that is used for printing books, newspapers, etc 印刷机

printout
/ˈprɪntaʊt ||; ˈprɪntˌaυt/noun [C,U] information from a computer that is printed onto paper （计算机）打印出来的数据，打印输出

prior
/ˈpraɪə(r) ||; ˈpraɪɚ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) coming before or earlier 在先的；在前的；较早的

prioritize
/praɪˈɒrətaɪz ||; praɪˈɔrəˌtaɪz/ (also -ise) verb
1 [I,T] to put tasks, problems, etc in order of importance, so that you can deal with the most important first （将任务、问题等）按优先次序排列: You should make a list of all the jobs you have to do and prioritize them. 你应当把所有要做的事按轻重缓急的顺序列个表。
2 [T] (formal 正式) to treat sth as being more important than other things （将某事）优先考虑: The organization was formed to prioritize the needs of older people. 建立这个组织是为了优先考虑老年人的需求。

*priority
/praɪˈɒrəti; US -ˈɔ:r- ||; praɪˈɔrətɪ/noun (plural priorities)
1 [U] priority (over sb/sth) the state of being more important than sb/sth or of coming before sb/sth else 优先（权）: We give priority to families with small children. 我们优先照顾有小孩的家庭。 Emergency cases take priority over other patients in hospital. 在医院里，急症病人较其他病人得到优先治疗。
2 [C] something that is most important or that you must do before anything else 最重要的事物；优先处理的事情；当务之急: Our top priority is to get food and water to the refugee camps. 我们的当务之急是把水和食物送到难民营。 I'll make it my priorityto sort out your problem. 我将优先解决你的问题。

ˈprior to
prep (formal 正式) before 在…之前: Passengers are asked to report to the check-in desk prior to departure. 乘客须在飞机起飞前到柜台办理登机手续。

prise
/praɪz ||; praɪz/ (especially US 尤为美 (prize)pry) verb [T] prise sth off, apart, open, etc to use force to open sth, remove a lid, etc （用力）撬，撬开，撬起（盖子等）: He prised the door open with an iron bar. 他用铁棍把门撬开了。

prism
/ˈprɪzəm ||; ˈprɪzəm/noun[C]
1 a solid object with ends that are parallel and of the same size and shape, and with sides whose opposite edges are equal and parallel 棱柱 ☞picture at solid 见solid插图
2 a transparent glass or plastic object which separates light that passes through it into the seven different colours 棱镜

*prison
/ˈprɪzn ||; ˈprɪzṇ/ (also jail) noun [C,U] a building where criminals are kept as a punishment 监狱: The terrorists were sent to prison for twenty-five years. 那帮恐怖分子被判入狱二十五年。 He will be released from prison next month. 他将于下月获释出狱。 ☞Look at imprison and jail. 参看imprison及jail。 If a person goes to prison or is in prison (without ‘ the ’), he/she has to stay there as a prisoner He was sent to prison for two years.‘The prison’ refers to a particular prison, or indicates that a person is only visiting the building temporarily The politician visited the prison and said that conditions were poor. 某人作为犯人入狱(go to prison)或在狱中(in prison)时，prison前面没有the：He was sent to prison for two years.他被关了两年。指某座监狱或某人只是去监狱探访一下时用the prison：The politician visited the prison and said that conditions were poor.那位政治家参观了这座监狱，说那里的条件很差。
*prisoner
/ˈprɪznə(r) ||; ˈprɪzṇɚ/noun [C] a person who is being kept in prison 犯人；囚犯: a political prisoner 政治犯

ˌprisoner of ˈwar
noun [C] (plural prisoners of war) (abbr POW) a soldier, etc who is caught by the enemy during a war and who is kept in prison until the end of the war 战俘

privacy
/ˈprɪvəsi ||; ˈpraɪvəsɪ/noun[U]
1 the state of being alone and not watched or disturbed by other people 清静；独处；不受干扰的状况: There is not much privacy in large hospital wards. 在医院的大病房里很难不受人干扰。
2 the state of being free from the attention of the public 隐私；私密性: The actress claimed that the photographs were an invasion of privacy. 那女演员声称，那些照片侵犯了隐私。

*private¹
/ˈpraɪvət ||; ˈpraɪvɪt/adj
1 belonging to or intended for one particular person or group and not to be shared by others 私有的；私人（用）的；专用的: This is private property. You may not park here. 这是私人产业，你不可以在这里停放车辆。 a private letter/conversation 私人信件╱谈话
2 not connected with work or business 与工作或业务无关的；个人的；私人的: He never discusses his private life with his colleagues at work. 他从来不与同事谈论自己的私生活。
3 owned, done or organized by a person or company, and not by the government 私立的；私营的；民办的；民营的: a private hospital/school (= you pay to go there) 私立医院╱学校 a private detective (= one who is not in the police) 私家侦探 ☞Look at public. 参看public。
4 with no one else present 没有其他人在场的；私下的；单独的: I would like a private interview with the personnel manager. 我想私下与人事部经理见面。
5 not wanting to share thoughts and feelings with other people 不喜欢跟别人谈论思想和感情的；孤僻的: He's a very private person. 他是个很不愿意谈论私事的人。
6 (used about classes, lessons, etc) given by a teacher to one student or a small group for payment （指办班、授课等）由一名老师向个别学生讲授的，自行开班授课的: Claire gives private English lessons at her house. 克莱尔在家里给学生上英语课。 ➔privately adv
private²
/ˈpraɪvət ||; ˈpraɪvɪt/noun [C] a soldier of the lowest level 列兵；二等兵 in private with no one else present 没有其他人在场；私下；单独: May I speak to you in private? 我可以单独跟你谈谈吗？

ˌprivate inˈvestigator
noun [C] (also ˌprivate deˈtective) (informal 非正式 ˌprivate ˈeye) a person who can be employed to find out information, look for a missing person, follow sb, etc 私人侦探

privatize
/ˈpraɪvɪtaɪz ||; ˈpraɪvətˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to sell a business or an industry that was owned by the government to a private company 将公司或企业由国有转为私有；私有化；民营化: The water industry has been privatized. 供水服务已经私营化。 [OPP] nationalize 反义词为nationalize ➔privatization(also -isation) /ˌpraɪvɪtaɪˈzeɪʃn ||; ˌpraɪvətəˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

*privilege
/ˈprɪvəlɪdʒ ||; ˈprɪvḷɪdʒ/noun
1 [C,U] a special right or advantage that only one person or group has 特权；特别待遇: Prisoners who behave well enjoy special privileges. 行为良好的囚犯可享有特别待遇。
2 [sing] a special advantage or opportunity that gives you great pleasure 特殊的待遇或机会；荣幸: It was a great privilege to hear her sing. 可以听她一展歌喉是难得的事。

privileged
/ˈprɪvəlɪdʒd ||; ˈprɪvḷɪdʒd/adj having an advantage or opportunity that most people do not have 享有特权的: Only a privileged few are allowed to enter this room. 只有少数享有特权的人获准进入这个房间。 I feel very privileged to be playing for the national team. 能为国家队出赛我感到非常荣幸。 [OPP] underprivileged 反义词为underprivileged

*prize¹
/praɪz ||; praɪz/noun [C] something of value that is given to sb who is successful in a race, competition, game, etc （优胜者所得的）奖品，奖金: She won first prize in the competition. 她在比赛中赢得头奖。 a prizewinning novel 一部获奖的小说
prize²
/praɪz ||; praɪz/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) winning, or good enough to win, a prize 获奖的；该获奖的: a prize flower display 获奖的花卉展品
prize³
/praɪz ||; praɪz/verb [T] to consider sth to be very valuable 重视；珍视: This picture is one of my most prized possessions. 这幅画是我最珍视的财产之一。
prize⁴
/praɪz ||; praɪz/ (especially US 尤为美) =PRISE

pro
/prəʊ ||; pro/noun [C] (plural pros) (informal 非正式)
1 a person who plays or teaches a sport for money 职业选手；职业教练: a golf pro 高尔夫球职业选手
2 a person who has a lot of skill and experience 专业人士 [SYN] professional 同义词为professional
the pros and cons the reasons for and against doing sth 赞成和反对的理由: We should consider all the pros and cons before reaching a decision. 在作出决定之前，我们应该考虑所有的利弊。

pro-
/prəʊ ||; pro/prefix (used in adjectives 用于构成形容词) in favour of; supporting 赞成；支持；亲: pro-democracy 赞成民主 pro-European 亲欧（洲）

proactive
/ˌprəʊˈæktɪv ||; proˈæktɪv/adj controlling a situation by making things happen rather than waiting for things to happen and then reacting to them 前摄的（使事情发生而不是等待事情发生，从而控制形势） ☞Compare reactive. 与reactive比较。 ➔proactively adv

probability
/ˌprɒbəˈbɪləti ||; ˌprɑbəˈbɪlətɪ/noun (plural probabilities)
1 [U] [sing] how likely sth is to happen 可能性；或然性；概率: At that time there seemed little probability of success. 在那时看来，似乎不大可能成功。
2 [C] something that is likely to happen 可能发生的事情: Closure of the factory now seems a probability. 那家工厂现在看来可能要倒闭。

*probable
/ˈprɒbəbl ||; ˈprɑbəbḷ/adj that you expect to happen or to be true; likely 大概会发生的；很可能成为事实的；很可能的 [OPP] improbable 反义词为improbable ☞Look at possible. 参看possible。 ☞Notice that probable and likely mean the same but are used differently It's probable that he will be late. He is likely to be late. 注意：probable和likely的意思相同，但用法不同：It's probable that he will be late.他大概会迟到。·He is likely to be late.他可能会迟到。

probably
/ˈprɒbəbli ||; ˈprɑbəblɪ/adv almost certainly 很可能；几乎肯定: I will phone next week, probably on Wednesday. 我下星期会打电话，很可能在星期三。

probation
/prəˈbeɪʃn; US prəʊ- ||; proˈbeʃən/noun[U]
1 a system that allows sb who has committed a crime not to go to prison if he/she goes to see to an official (a probation officer) regularly for a fixed period of time 缓刑制（犯罪后被准许不坐牢，但须定期去见缓刑监督官）: Jamie is on probation for two years. 杰米被判缓刑两年。
2 a period of time at the start of a new job when you are tested to see if you are suitable 试用期: a three-month probation period 三个月的试用期

probe¹
/prəʊb ||; prob/verb[I,T]
1 probe (into sth) to ask questions in order to find out secret or hidden information 查问；探查；探究: The newspapers are now probing into the President's past. 报纸目前正在调查总统的过去。
2 to examine or look for sth, especially with a long thin instrument 探查，探测（尤指用细长的仪器）: The doctor probed the cut for pieces of broken glass. 医生在伤口里寻找碎玻璃片。 ➔probing adj to ask probing questions 提出探索性的问题
probe²
/prəʊb ||; prob/noun[C]
1 the process of asking questions, collecting facts, etc in order to find out hidden information about sth 调查；探查；查问: a police probe into illegal financial dealing 警方对非法金融交易的调查
2 a long thin tool that you use for examining sth that is difficult to reach, especially a part of the body 探针，探子（用于探查某物，尤指身体部位）

*problem
/ˈprɒbləm ||; ˈprɑbləm/noun[C]
1 a thing that is difficult to deal with or to understand 困难的情况；问题；难题: social/family/financial/technical problems 社会╱家庭╱财政╱技术问题 You won't solve the problem if you ignore it. 如果对问题视而不见，问题就得不到解决。 The company will face problems from unions if it sacks workers. 公司如果解雇工人，就会面临来自工会的难题。 It's going to cause problems if Donna brings her husband. 要是唐娜带着丈夫来，就会引起麻烦。 I can't play because I've got a problem with my knee. 我无法参赛，因为我的膝盖不舒服。 ‘Can you fix this for me?’ ‘ No problem.’ “你可以替我修理一下这个吗？”“没问题。” It's a great painting -- the problem is I've got nowhere to put it. 这是一幅好画，问题是我没有地方摆。
2 a question that you have to solve by thinking about it 问题；课题；习题: a maths/logic problem 数学题；逻辑题

problematic
/ˌprɒbləˈmætɪk ||; ˌprɑbləˈmætɪk/ (also problematical /-ɪkl ||; -ɪkḷ/) adj difficult to deal with or to understand; full of problems; not certain to be successful 难对付或理解的；问题多的；无把握的: Finding replacement parts for such an old car could be problematic. 为这样一辆旧车找零配件可能难以办到。 [OPP] unproblematic 反义词为unproblematic

*procedure
/prəˈsi:dʒə(r) ||; prəˈsidʒɚ/noun [C,U] the usual or correct way for doing sth 程序；手续；步骤: What's the procedure for making a complaint? 投诉要依照什么程序？

*proceed
/prəˈsi:d;proʊ-||; prəˈsid/verb[I]
1 (formal 正式) to continue doing sth; to continue being done 继续进行下去；持续: The building work was proceeding according to schedule. 建筑工程按计划进行。
2 (formal 正式)proceed (with sth/to do sth) to start doing the next thing after finishing the last one 接着做（别的事情）: Once he had calmed down he proceeded to tell us what had happened. 他一平静下来，便开始告诉我们发生了什么事。

proceedings
/prəˈsi:dɪŋz ||; prəˈsidɪŋz/noun[pl]
1 proceedings (against sb/for sth) legal action 法律行动；诉讼（程序）: to start divorce proceedings 展开离婚诉讼
2 events that happen, especially at a formal meeting, ceremony, etc （尤指正式会议、典礼等的）议程，项目，节目: The proceedings were interrupted by demonstrators. 议程被示威者打断了。

proceeds
/ˈprəʊsi:dz ||; ˈprosidz/noun [pl] proceeds (of/from sth) money that you get when you sell sth （出售物品所得的）收入，收益: The proceeds from the sale will go to charity. 这次销售的收益将捐作慈善用途。

*process¹
/ˈprəʊses; US ˈprɒses ||; ˈprɑsɛs/noun[C]
1 a series of actions that you do for a particular purpose 步骤；程序；进程；过程: We've just begun the complicated process of selling the house. 我们刚刚开始办理卖房子的复杂手续。
2 a series of changes that happen naturally （自然发生的）变化过程: Mistakes are part of the learning process. 出错是学习过程的组成部份。
in the process while you are doing sth else 在（进行某事）的过程中: We washed the dog yesterday -- and we all got very wet in the process. 昨天我们给狗洗澡的时候，大家都弄得浑身湿透了。 in the process of sth/doing sth in the middle of doing sth 在（进行某事）的过程中: They are in the process of moving house. 他们正在搬家呢。
process²
/ˈprəʊses ||; ˈprɑsɛs/verb[T]
1 to treat sth, for example with chemicals, in order to keep it, change it, etc （对某物）进行加工，处理: Cheese is processed so that it lasts longer. 干酪经过加工，以便保存久一点。 I sent two rolls of film away to be processed. 我送了两个胶卷去冲洗。
2 to deal with information, for example on a computer （用计算机等）处理信息: It will take about ten days to process your application. 处理你的申请大约需时十天。

procession
/prəˈseʃn ||; prəˈsɛʃən/noun [C,U] a number of people, vehicles, etc that move slowly in a line, especially as part of a ceremony （人、车等）缓慢前进的行列或队伍（尤见于仪式中）: to walk in procession 列队行进 a funeral procession 送葬行列

processor
/ˈprəʊsesə(r) ||; ˈprɑsɛsɚ/noun[C]
1 a machine or a person that processes things 加工器；处理者 ☞Look at food processor and word processor. 参看food processor及word processor。
2 (computing计算机技术) a part of a computer that controls all the other parts of the system 处理器；处理机

ˌpro-ˈchoice
adj believing that a pregnant woman should be able to choose to have an abortion if she wants 提倡堕胎合法的；主张自由选择人工流产的: pro-choice activists 积极提倡堕胎合法的人 ☞ Look at pro-life⇒. 参看 pro-life⇒。

proclaim
/prəˈkleɪm ||; proˈklem/verb [T] (written 书面语) to make sth known officially or publicly （正式）宣布，宣告，公布: The day was proclaimed a national holiday. 这一天被宣布为全国假日。 ➔proclamation /ˌprɒkləˈmeɪʃn ||; ˌprɑkləˈmeʃən/ noun [C,U] to make a proclamation of war 宣战

procure
/prəˈkjʊə(r) ||; proˈkjυr/verb [T] (written 书面语)procure sth (for sb) to obtain sth, especially with difficulty 获得，取得（尤指困难地）: I managed to procure two tickets for the match. 我设法弄到两张那场比赛的票。

prod
/prɒd ||; prɑd/verb [I,T] (prodding;prodded) to push or press sb/sth with your finger or a pointed object （用手指或尖物）刺，戳，捅: (figurative 比喻) Ruth works quite hard but she does need prodding occasionally. 鲁思工作颇努力，但偶尔也需要有人督促一下。 ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图 prod noun [C]: to give the fire a prod with a stick 用棒把炉火拨旺 ➔prodding noun [U]

prodigious
/prəˈdɪdʒəs ||; prəˈdɪdʒəs/adj very large or powerful and surprising 巨大的；庞大的；惊人的: He seemed to have a prodigious amount of energy. 他好像有过人的精力。

prodigy
/ˈprɒdədʒi ||; ˈprɑdədʒɪ/noun [C] (plural prodigies) a child who is unusually good at sth 神童: Mozart was a child prodigy. 莫扎特是个神童。 ☞Look at genius. 参看genius。

*produce¹
/prəˈdju:s; US -ˈdu:s ||; prəˈdus/verb[T]
1 to make sth to be sold, especially in large quantities （尤指大批量）制造，生产: The factory produces 20000 cars a year. 那家工厂每年制造20000辆汽车。 [SYN] manufacture 同义词为manufacture
2 to grow or make sth by a natural process 种植；出产: This region produces most of the country's wheat. 这个地区出产该国大部份的小麦。 (figurative 比喻) He's the greatest athlete this country has produced. 他是这个国家产生的最了不起的运动员。
3 to create sth using skill 创作: The children have produced some beautiful pictures for the exhibition. 孩子们为这个展览会创作了几幅漂亮的画。
4 to cause a particular effect or result 引起，引致，招致（影响或结果）: Her remarks produced roars of laughter. 她的话引起哄堂大笑。
5 to show sth so that sb else can look at or examine it 出示；拿出；提出: to produce evidence in court 在法庭上提出证据
6 to be in charge of preparing a film, play, etc so that it can be shown to the public 制作，演出，上演，放映（电影、戏剧等）: She is producing ‘Romeo and Juliet’ at the local theatre. 她正在当地的剧院演出《罗密欧与朱丽叶》。
produce²
/ˈprɒdju:s; US -du:s ||; ˈprɑdus/noun [U] food, etc that is grown on a farm and sold 农产品；农作物: fresh farm produce 新鲜的农产品 ☞Look at the note at production. 参看production的注释。

producer
/prəˈdju:sə(r); US -ˈdu:- ||; prəˈdusɚ/noun[C]
1 a person, company or country that makes or grows sth 生产者；制造商；出产国: Brazil is a major producer of coffee. 巴西是咖啡的主要出产国。
2 a person who deals with the business side of organizing a play, film, etc （戏剧、电影等的）监制，制片
3 a person who arranges for sb to make a programme for television or radio, or a record （电视、电台节目或唱片的）监制

*product
/ˈprɒdʌkt ||; ˈprɑdʌkt/noun[C]
1 something that is made in a factory or that is formed naturally 产品；制品；产物: dairy/meat/pharmaceutical/software products 奶制品；肉制品；药品；软件产品 Carbon dioxide is one of the waste products of this process. 二氧化碳是这个过程所产生的废料之一。
2 product of sth the result of sth 结果；成果: The industry's problems are the product of government policy. 这个行业的种种问题是政府政策造成的恶果。
3 the amount that you get if you multiply one number by another （乘法运算的）积: The product of three and five is fifteen. 三乘五的积是十五。

*production
/prəˈdʌkʃn ||; prəˈdʌkʃən/noun
1 [U] the making or growing of sth, especially in large quantities （尤指大量的）制造，生产: The latest model will be in production from April. 最新的型号从四月起投产。 This farm specializes in the production of organic vegetables. 这农场专门生产施用有机肥料的蔬菜。 mass production 批量生产
2 [U] the amount of sth that is made or grown 产量: a rise/fall in production 产量增加╱减少 a high level of production 高水平的产量
3 [C] a play, film or programme that has been made for the public （为公演制作的）戏剧，电影，节目 ☞Notice that produce (noun) means food, etc that comes from a farm and a product is something that was made in a factory. A production is a play, film, etc The label on the bottle says ‘Produce of Italy’. The company's main products are plastic toys. the Bolshoi Ballet's production of Swan Lake 注意：produce指农场出产的食物等；product指工厂制造的产品；而production则是指戏剧、电影等：The label on the bottle says ‘Produce of Italy’.瓶上的卷标写着“意大利产品”。·The company's main products are plastic toys.公司的主要制品是塑料玩具。·the Bolshoi Ballet's production of Swan Lake大剧院芭蕾舞团演出的芭蕾舞剧《天鹅湖》
on production of sth when you show sth 出示: You can get a ten per cent discount on production of your membership card. 出示会员证可获九折优待。

productive
/prəˈdʌktɪv ||; prəˈdʌktɪv/adj
1 that makes or grows sth, especially in large quantities 有生产力的；肥沃的；多产的: The company wants to sell off its less productive factories. 公司要把那些产能较低的工厂出售。
2 useful (because results come from it) 有成效的: a productive discussion 富有成效的讨论 ➔productivity /ˌprɒdʌkˈtɪvəti ||; ˌprɑdʌkˈtɪvətɪ/ noun [U]

Prof.
abbr (written 书面语) Professor 教授

profess
/prəˈfes ||; prəˈfɛs/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to say that sth is true or correct, even when it is not 声称；伪称；妄称: Marianne professed to know nothing at all about it, but I did not believe her. 玛丽安娜声称对那事一无所知，但是我不相信她。
2 to state honestly that you have a particular belief, feeling, etc 诚实表明（信念、感受等）: He professed his hatred of war. 他坦诚表明厌恶战争。

*profession
/prəˈfeʃn ||; prəˈfɛʃən/noun[C]
1 a job that needs a high level of training and/or education 专业: the medical/legal/teaching profession 医学╱法律╱教育专业 She's thinking of entering the nursing profession. 她正考虑投身护理专业。 ☞Look at the note at work ². 参看work^2的注释。
2 the...profession [with.sop] all the people who work in a particular profession （统称）从事某专业的人: The legal profession is/are trying to resist the reforms. 法律界人士正设法抵制这些改革。
by profession as your job 作为专业或职业: George is an accountant by profession. 乔治的职业是会计师。

*professional¹
/prəˈfeʃənl ||; prəˈfɛʃənḷ/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with a job that needs a high level of training and/or education 专业的；职业的: Get professional advice from your lawyer before you take any action. 采取任何行动之前，应先征询你的律师的专业意见。
2 doing sth in a way that shows skill, training or care 在行的；胜任的；专业的: The police are trained to deal with every situation in a calm and professional manner. 警察都受过训练，能够以冷静而专业的方式应付各种情况。 Her application was neatly typed and looked very professional. 她的申请书打得很整洁，看来很有专业水平。 [OPP] unprofessional 反义词为unprofessional
3 doing a sport, etc as a job or for money; (used about a sport, etc) done by people who are paid 职业的；领薪的: He's planning to turn professional after the Olympics. 他打算在奥林匹克运动会后转为职业运动员。 professional football 职业足球 [OPP] amateur 反义词为amateur
*professional²
/prəˈfeʃənl ||; prəˈfɛʃənḷ/noun[C]
1 a person who works in a job that needs a high level of training and/or education 专业人士
2 (informal 非正式pro) a person who plays or teaches a sport, etc for money 职业选手；职业教练
3 (informal 非正式pro) a person who has a lot of skill and experience 内行；专家

professionalism
/prəˈfeʃənəlɪzəm ||; prəˈfɛʃənəlˌɪzəm/noun [U] a way of doing a job that shows great skill and experience 专业作风；专业精神: We were impressed by the professionalism of the staff. 员工的专业精神给我们留下深刻印象。

professionally
/prəˈfeʃənəli ||; prəˈfɛʃənḷɪ/adv
1 in a way that shows great skill and experience 专业地；以专业工作方式
2 for money; by a professional person 受薪；由专业人士担任: Rob plays the saxophone professionally. 罗布专职吹萨克斯管。

*professor
/prəˈfesə(r) ||; prəˈfɛsɚ/noun [C] (abbr Prof.)
1 a university teacher of the highest level （大学）教授: She's professor of English at Bristol University. 她是布里斯托尔大学的英语教授。
2 (US 美) a teacher at a college or university （学院或大学的）教师，教员

proficient
/prəˈfɪʃnt ||; prəˈfɪʃənt/adj proficient (in/at sth/doing sth) able to do a particular thing well; skilled 精通的；熟练的: We are looking for someone who is proficient in French. 我们正在找一个精通法语的人。 ➔proficiency noun [U]: proficiency (in sth/doing sth) a certificate of proficiency in English 英语程度证书

profile
/ˈprəʊfaɪl ||; ˈprofaɪl/noun[C]
1 a person's face or head seen from the side, not the front （面部或头部的）侧面，侧影: I did a sketch of him in profile. 我为他画了一幅侧面素描。
2 a short description of sb/sth that gives useful information 简介；传略；相关资料: We're building up a profile of our average customer. 我们正在逐步建立一般顾客的相关数据。
a high/low profile a way of behaving that does/does not attract other people's attention 高╱低姿态: I don't know much about the subject -- I'm going to keep a low profile at the meeting tomorrow. 我对那个题目所知不多，明天的会议上我会保持低调。

profiling
/prəʊfaɪlɪŋ ||; ˈprofaɪlɪŋ/noun[U]
1 the act of stopping and searching people who belong to a particular race or group, for example by the police or at an airport, because they are believed to be more likely to commit crimes ﹙歧视性﹚搜身检查: racial profiling 基于种族歧视的搜身检查
2 the process of collecting and analysing information about sb/sth in order to build up a picture of what he/she/it is like ﹙有关人或事物的﹚数据搜集，特征分析: customer profiling 客户特征分析

*profit¹
/ˈprɒfɪt ||; ˈprɑfɪt/noun [C,U] the money that you make when you sell sth for more than it costs you 利润；利得: Did you make a profit on your house when you sold it? 你出售你的房子赚了钱吗？ I'm hoping to sell my shares at a profit. 我希望获利出售所持股票。 ☞Look at loss. 参看loss。
profit²
/ˈprɒfɪt ||; ˈprɑfɪt/verb [I,T] (formal 正式)profit (from/by sth) to get an advantage from sth; to give sb an advantage 从…中得到好处；使（某人）获益: Who will profit most from the tax reforms? 税制改革对谁最有利？

profitable
/ˈprɒfɪtəbl ||; ˈprɑfɪtəbḷ/adj
1 that makes money 有利可图的；赚钱的: a profitable business 有利可图的生意
2 helpful or useful 有益的；有用的: We had a very profitable discussion yesterday. 昨天我们进行了一次有益的讨论。 ➔profitably adv to spend your time profitably 善用时间 ➔profitability /ˌprɒfɪtəˈbɪləti ||; ˌprɑfɪtəˈbɪlətɪ/ noun [U]

ˌprofit and ˈloss account
noun [C] (technical术语) a written record of the amounts of money that a business or organization earns and spends in a particular period 损益账

ˈprofit margin
noun [C] the difference between the cost of buying or producing sth and the price that it is sold for 利润率；利润幅度

pro forma
/ˌprəʊ ˈfɔ:mə ||; pro ˈfɔrmə/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (technical术语)
1 (used especially about a document) prepared in order to show the usual way of doing sth or to provide a standard method （尤指文件）作为说明或范例的，形式的: a pro-forma letter 书信范例 pro-forma instructions 形式说明
2 (used about a document) sent in advance （指文件）提前发出的: a pro-forma invoice (= a document that gives details of the goods being sent to a customer) 估价发票 pro forma noun [C]: I enclose a pro forma for you to complete, sign and return. 内附一份形式发票，请你填好后签字发回。

profound
/prəˈfaʊnd ||; prəˈfaυnd/adj
1 very great; that you feel very strongly 极大的；深刻的；深切的: The experience had a profound influence on her. 那经历对她有巨大的影响。
2 needing or showing a lot of knowledge or thought 深奥的；渊博的: He's always making profound statements about the meaning of life. 他经常说一些有关生命意义的深奥说话。 ➔profoundly adv I was profoundly relieved to hear the news. 听到那消息使我如释重负。

profuse
/prəˈfju:s ||; prəˈfjus/adj (formal 正式) given or produced in great quantity 大量的；丰富的: profuse apologies 再三道歉 ➔profusely adv She apologized profusely for being late. 她为迟到一再道歉。

profusion
/prəˈfju:ʒn ||; prəˈfjuʒən/noun [sing] [with.sop] [U] (formal 正式) a very large quantity of sth 大量；丰富: a profusion of colours/flowers 色彩缤纷；大量花卉 Roses grew in profusion against the old wall. 老墙边的玫瑰长得很茂盛。

progesterone
/prəˈdʒestərəʊn ||; proˈdʒɛstɚˌon/noun [U] a substance(hormone)produced in the bodies of women and female animals which prepares the body to become pregnant 孕酮，黄体酮（一种性激素，产生于妇女及雌性动物体内，使身体为怀孕作好准备） ☞Look at oestrogen and testosterone. 参看oestrogen及testosterone。

prognosis
/prɒgˈnəʊsɪs ||; prɑgˈnosɪs/noun [C] (plural prognoses /-si:z ||; -siz/)
1 (medical医学) an opinion, based on medical experience, of the likely development of a disease or an illness 预后（凭医疗经验对疾病发展的预测）
2 (formal 正式) a judgement about how sth is likely to develop in the future 预测: The prognosis is for more people to work part-time in the future. 预测未来有更多人做非全日制工作。

*program¹
/ˈprəʊgræm; US -grəm ||; ˈprogrəm/noun[C]
1 a set of instructions that you give to a computer so that it will do a particular task （计算机的）程序，程序: to write a program 编写一个程序
When we are talking about computers both the American and the British spelling is program. For every other meaning the British spelling is programme and the American spelling is program. 指计算机程序时，美国英语及英国英语的拼法都是program。指其他意义时，英国英语的拼法是programme，而美国英语的拼法是program。
2 (US 美) =PROGRAMME¹
*program²
/ˈprəʊgræm ||; ˈprogrəm/verb [I,T] (programming;programmed) to give a set of instructions to a computer 把指令输入（计算机）；发出指令

*programme¹
/ˈprəʊgræm; US -grəm ||; ˈprogrəm/ (US 美 program) noun [C]
1 a show or other item that is sent out on the radio or television （电台或电视）节目: a TV/radio programme 电视╱电台节目 We've just missed an interesting programme on elephants. 我们刚错过了一个介绍大象的精彩节目。
2 a plan of things to do; a scheme 计划；程序: What's (on) your programme today? (= what are you going to do today?) 今天你有什么事情要做？ The leaflet outlines the government's programme of educational reforms. 这份传单概述政府的教育改革计划。
3 a little book or piece of paper which you get at a concert, a sports event, etc that gives you information about what you are going to see （音乐会、体育比赛等的）节目表，节目单，程序表
programme²
/ˈprəʊgræm ||; ˈprogrəm/ (US 美 program) verb [T] (programming;programmed (US also 美亦作) programing;programed)
1 to plan for sth to happen at a particular time 为…制订计划；规划: The road is programmed for completion next May. 这条道路计划明年五月完工。
2 to make sb/sth work or act automatically in a particular way 使按某方式自动地工作或运作: The lights are programmed to come on as soon as it gets dark. 经过设定，电灯天一黑就会自动亮起。

programmer
/ˈprəʊgræmə(r) ||; ˈprogrəmɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to write programs for a computer （计算机）程序设计员，程序设计师

*progress¹
/ˈprəʊgres; US ˈprɒg- ||; ˈprɑgrɛs/noun[U]
1 movement forwards or towards achieving sth 行进；前进；进展: Anna's making progress at school. 安娜的学业在进步。 to make slow/steady/rapid/good progress 取得缓慢╱持续╱迅速╱很大进步
2 change or improvement in society （社会的）改进，改变，进步: scientific progress 科学的进步
in progress happening now 进行中: Silence! Examination in progress. 请安静！考试正在进行。
progress²
/prəˈgres ||; prəˈgrɛs/verb[I]
1 to become better; to develop (well) 改善；进步；发展（良好）: Medical knowledge has progressed rapidly in the last twenty years. 在过去二十年里，医学知识发展迅速。
2 to move forward; to continue 前进；继续: I got more and more tired as the evening progressed. 夜渐深，我越来越累。

progression
/prəˈgreʃn ||; prəˈgrɛʃən/noun [C,U] (a) progression (from sth) (to sth) movement forward or a development from one stage to another 前进；行进；（由一阶段至另一阶段的）发展，进展: You've made the progression from beginner to intermediate level. 你已经从初学者渐渐达到中等程度。

progressive
/prəˈgresɪv ||; prəˈgrɛsɪv/adj
1 using modern methods and ideas 使用现代方法和理念的；先进的: a progressive school 一所采用先进教学法的学校
2 happening or developing steadily 稳步发展的；渐进的: a progressive reduction in the number of staff 职员数目逐渐减少

progressively
/prəˈgresɪvli ||; prəˈgrɛsɪvlɪ/adv steadily; a little at a time 稳步；逐渐: The situation became progressively worse. 情况逐渐恶化。

prohibit
/prəˈhɪbɪt; US prəʊ- ||; proˈhɪbɪt/verb [T] (formal 正式)prohibit sb/sth (from doing sth) to say that sth is not allowed by law; to forbid （法律）禁止: English law prohibits children under 16 from buying cigarettes. 英国法律禁止16岁以下儿童购买香烟。

prohibition
/ˌprəʊɪˈbɪʃn; US ˌprəʊəˈbɪʃn ||; ˌproəˈbɪʃən/noun
1 [C] (formal 正式)a prohibition (on/against sth) a law or rule that forbids sth 禁令: There is a prohibition on the carrying of knives. 有一项禁止携带刀子的法律。
2 [U] the action of stopping sth being done or used, especially by law 禁止（尤指根据法律）: the prohibition of alcohol in the 1920s 20世纪20年代的禁酒

prohibitive
/prəˈhɪbətɪv; US prəʊ- ||; proˈhɪbɪtɪv/adj (used about a price or cost) so high that it prevents people from buying sth or doing sth （指价格或费用）高得吓人的，使人不敢问津的，过分昂贵的: The price of houses in the centre of town is prohibitive. 市中心的房价高得令人不敢问津。 ➔prohibitively adv

*project¹
/ˈprɒdʒekt ||; ˈprɑdʒɛkt/noun[C]
1 a piece of work, often involving many people, that is planned and organized carefully 计划；工程；项目: a major project to reduce pollution in our rivers 一项减少我国河流污染的大型工程
2 a piece of school work in which the student has to collect information about a certain subject and then write about it （学校的）研究项目，作业，课题: Our group chose to do a project on rainforests. 我们这一组决定做一项关于雨林的研究。
project²
/prəˈdʒekt ||; prəˈdʒɛkt/verb
1 [T] (usually passive 常用于被动语态) to plan sth that will happen in the future 计划；打算: the band's projected world tour 该乐队计划中的世界巡回演出
2 [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to guess or calculate the size, cost or amount of sth 估计；估算: a projected increase of 10% 估计增长率为10%
3 [T] project sth (on/onto sth) to make light, a picture from a film, etc appear on a flat surface or screen 投射，放映（光线、电影影像等）
4 [T] to show or represent sb/sth/yourself in a certain way 以某种方式表现某人、某物或自己: The government is trying to project a more caring image. 政府正设法要树立一种较为亲民的形象。
5 [I] (formal 正式) to stick out 伸出；突出: The balcony projects one metre out from the wall. 阳台从外墙向外伸出一米。
6 [T] to send or throw sth upwards or away from you （向上或向外）发出，抛出: Actors have to learn to project their voice. 演员必须学会运气发声。

projectile
/prəˈdʒektaɪl ||; prəˈdʒɛktḷ/noun [C] (formal 正式)or(technical术语)
1 an object, such as a bullet, that is fired from a gun or other weapon 射弹（如枪等武器射出的子弹）
2 any object that is thrown as a weapon 抛射物

projection
/prəˈdʒekʃn ||; prəˈdʒɛkʃən/noun
1 [C] a guess about a future amount, situation, etc based on the present situation （根据目前情况对未来的数量、情况等所作的）预测，估计，推测: sales projections for the next five years 未来五年的估计销售额
2 [U] the act of making light, a picture from a film, etc appear on a surface （光线、电影影像等的）投影，投射，放映

projector
/prəˈdʒektə(r) ||; prəˈdʒɛktɚ/noun [C] a piece of equipment that projects pictures or films onto a screen or wall 放映机；投影机；幻灯机: a film/slide/overhead projector 电影放映机；幻灯机；高射投影机

ˌpro-ˈlife
adj opposed to the belief that a pregnant woman should be able to choose to have an abortion if she wants 反堕胎的；反对人工流产的: a pro-life campaigner 反堕胎运动成员 ☞ Look at pro-choice⇒. 参看 prochoice⇒。

proliferate
/prəˈlɪfəreɪt; US prəʊ- ||; proˈlɪfəˌret/verb [I] (formal 正式) to increase quickly in number （数量）激增，迅速增加 ➔proliferation /prəˌlɪfəˈreɪʃn; US prəʊ- ||; proˌlɪfəˈreʃən/ noun [U]

prolific
/prəˈlɪfɪk ||; prəˈlɪfɪk/adj (used especially about a writer, artist, etc) producing a lot （尤指作家、艺术家等）多产的，作品丰富的: a prolific goal scorer 踢进许多球的射手

prologue
/ˈprəʊlɒg; US ˈprəʊlɔ:g ||; ˈprolɔg/noun [C] a piece of writing or a speech that introduces a play, poem, etc （戏剧等的）开场白，引子；（诗的）序篇 ☞Look at epilogue. 参看epilogue。

prolong
/prəˈlɒŋ; US -ˈlɔ:ŋ ||; prəˈlɔŋ/verb [T] to make sth last longer 延长；拖延；使维持更久

prolonged
/prəˈlɒŋd ||; prəˈlɔŋd/adj continuing for a long time 持续很久的；长期的: There was a prolonged silence before anybody spoke. 经过一段长时间的沉默后，人们才开始发言。

prom
/prɒm ||; prɑm/noun[C]
1 =PROMENADE
2 (US 美) a formal dance that is held by a high school class at the end of a school year （中学每学年结束时举行的）班级舞会

promenade
/ˌprɒməˈnɑ:d; US -ˈneɪd ||; ˌprɑməˈned/ (also prom) noun [C] a wide path where people walk beside the sea in a town on the coast 海滨散步道；海滨人行步道 ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图

prominent
/ˈprɒmɪnənt ||; ˈprɑmənənt/adj
1 important or famous 重要的；著名的: a prominent political figure 一位著名的政界人物
2 noticeable; easy to see 显著的；突出的；显眼的: The church is the most prominent feature of the village. 那座教堂是村子里最显著的特色。 ➔prominence noun [U]: The newspaper gave the affair great prominence. 那家报纸突出报道了这段恋情。 ➔prominently adv

promiscuous
/prəˈmɪskjuəs ||; prəˈmɪskjυəs/adj having sexual relations with many people 滥交的；与很多人有性关系的 ➔promiscuity /ˌprɒmɪˈskju:əti ||; ˌprɒmɪsˈkjuətɪ/ noun [U]

*promise¹
/ˈprɒmɪs ||; ˈprɑmɪs/verb
1 [I,T] promise (to do sth);promise (sb) that... to say definitely that you will do or not do sth or that sth will happen 答应；允诺；承诺 · She promised (me) that she would write every week. 她（向我）保证每星期都会写信。 She promised not to forget to write. 她答应过不会忘记写信。
2 [T] promise sth (to sb);promise sb sth to say definitely that you will give sth to sb 答应给予: Can you promise your support? 你可以答应支持我吗？ My dad has promised me a bicycle. 父亲答应了给我买一辆自行车。 You have to give him the money if you promised it to him. 如果你答应过要给他这笔钱，就得把钱给他。
3 [T] to show signs of sth, so that you expect it to happen 有（某事将会发生的）迹象；预示: It promises to be an exciting occasion. 看来这会是个令人兴奋的时刻。
*promise²
/ˈprɒmɪs ||; ˈprɑmɪs/noun
1 [C] a promise (to do sth/that...) a written or spoken statement or agreement that you will or will not do sth 约定；协定；诺言: I want you to make a promise that you won't do that again. 我要你保证不再做那种事。 Make sure you keep your promiseto always do your homework. 你务必信守做家庭作业的承诺。 You should never break a promise. 你绝对不该违背诺言。 I give you my promisethat I won't tell anyone. 我向你保证，我不会告诉任何人。
2 [U] signs that you will be able to do sth well or be successful 可望成功的迹象；有希望: He showed great promiseas a musician. 他极有希望成为音乐家。

promising
/ˈprɒmɪsɪŋ ||; ˈprɑmɪsɪŋ/adj showing signs of being very good or successful 有前途的；大有可为的: a promising young writer 有前途的年轻作家

promo
/prəʊməʊ ||; ˈpromo/noun [C] (plural promos) an advertisement to promote (2) sth, especially in the form of a short film/movie or video 推销广告；宣传片: to make a new promo for the game show 为有奖游戏节目做新的广告 ➔promo adj (informal 非正式): a promo video 促销录像

promontory
/ˈprɒməntri ||; ˈprɑmənˌtɔrɪ/noun [C] (plural -ies) a long narrow area of high land that goes out into the sea （突入海中的）岬角: a rocky promontory overlooking the bay 多岩的岬角俯瞰海湾

promote
/prəˈməʊt ||; prəˈmot/verb[T]
1 to encourage sth; to help sth to happen or develop 促进；促使；推动: to promote good relations between countries 增进国家间的友好关系
2 promote sth (as sth) to advertise sth in order to increase its sales or make it popular 宣传，推销（以增销量或受欢迎程度）: The new face cream is being promoted as a miracle cure for wrinkles. 这新的面霜被宣传为一种去除皱纹的神药。
3 promote sb (from sth) (to sth) (often passive 常用于被动语态) to give sb a higher position or more important job 提升；擢升: He's been promoted from assistant manager to manager. 他已由助理经理晋升为经理。 [OPP] demote 反义词为demote

promoter
/prəˈməʊtə(r) ||; prəˈmotɚ/noun [C] a person who organizes or provides the money for an event 组织者；筹划人；赞助人；资助人

*promotion
/prəˈməʊʃn ||; prəˈmoʃən/noun
1 [C,U] promotion (to sth) a move to a higher position or more important job 提升；晋级；晋升: The new job is a promotion for her. 这个新职务对她来说是一次晋升。 [OPP] demotion 反义词为demotion
2 [U] [C] things that you do in order to advertise a product and increase its sales 宣传；推广；促销: It's all part of a special promotion of the new book. 这都是该新书促销活动的一环。
3 [U] (formal 正式)promotion (of sth) the activity of trying to make sth develop or become accepted by people 促进；提倡: We need to work on the promotion of health, not the treatment of disease. 我们需要在促进保健方面努力，而不是在治病方面。

*prompt¹
/prɒmpt ||; prɑmpt/adj
1 immediate; done without delay 实时的；迅速的；立即的: We need a prompt decision on this matter. 我们需要立刻对这件事作出决定。
2 prompt (in doing sth/to do sth) (not before a noun 不用于名词前) (used about a person) quick; acting without delay （指人）敏捷，行动迅速: We are always prompt in paying our bills. 我们一向都及时付账。 She was prompt to point out my mistake. 她很快便指出了我的错处。
prompt²
/prɒmpt ||; prɑmpt/verb
1 [T] to cause sth to happen; to make sb decide to do sth 引致；促使；驱使: What prompted you to give up your job? 什么驱使你放弃你的工作呢？
2 [I,T] to encourage sb to speak by asking questions or to remind an actor of his/her words in a play （通过提问）鼓励某人说话；（为演员）提词 · The speaker had to be prompted several times. 讲话者要别人多次提示才能说下去。 ➔prompting noun [U]: He apologized without any prompting. 他不用别人提醒就道歉了。
prompt³
/prɒmpt ||; prɑmpt/noun[C]
1 a word or words said to an actor to remind him/her of what to say next （对演员的）提词，提示: When she forgot her lines I had to give her a prompt. 她忘记台词的时候，我就得提示她一下。
2 (computing计算机技术) a sign on a computer screen that shows that the computer has finished what it was doing and is ready for more instructions （计算机屏幕上的）提示符（表示任务已经完成，准备接受新的指令）: Wait for the prompt to come up then type in your password. 等提示符出现，然后键入密码。

promptly
/ˈprɒmptli ||; ˈprɑmptlɪ/adv
1 immediately; without delay 立即；马上；实时: I invited her to dinner and she promptly accepted. 我邀请她吃晚饭，她立即答应了。
2 (also prompt) at exactly the time that you have arranged; punctually 于安排的时候；准时: We arrived promptly at 12 o'clock. 我们12点正准时到达。 I'll pick you up at 7 o'clock prompt. 我7点正来接你。

prone
/prəʊn ||; pron/adj prone to sth/to do sth likely to suffer from sth or to do sth bad 很可能遭受（某坏事）；很可能做（某坏事）: prone to infection/injury/heart attacks 容易感染；容易受到伤害；容易心脏病发作 Working without a break makes you more prone to error. 连续不停地工作使人比较容易出差错。 to be accident-prone(= to have a lot of accidents) 容易发生意外

prong
/prɒŋ ||; prɔŋ/noun[C]
1 each of the two or more long pointed parts of a fork （叉子的）尖齿
2 each of the separate parts of an attack, argument, etc that sb uses to achieve sth （攻击、争论等的）每一个别部份，分支，路，股
3 -pronged (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the number or type of prongs mentioned 有…尖齿或分支的；分…股、路或方面的: a three-pronged attack 兵分三路出击

pronoun
/ˈprəʊnaʊn ||; ˈpronaυn/noun [C] (grammar语法) a word that is used in place of a noun or a phrase that contains a noun 代词: ‘He’, ‘it’, ‘hers’, ‘me’, ‘them’, etc are all pronouns. he、it、hers、me、them等全都是代词。 ☞Look also at personal pronoun. 另参看personal pronoun。

*pronounce
/prəˈnaʊns ||; prəˈnaυns/verb
1 [T] to make the sound of a word or letter in a particular way 发（词或字母的）音；念: You don't pronounce the ‘b’ at the end of ‘comb’. comb的最后一个字母b不发音。 How do you pronounce your surname? 你的姓怎么念？ ☞noun pronunciation 名词为pronunciation
2 [T] (formal 正式) to say or give sth formally, officially or publicly （正式或公开地）表示，宣称，宣布: The judge will pronounce sentence today. 法官将于今天宣判。
3 [I,T] (formal 正式)pronounce (on sth) to give your opinion on sth, especially formally （尤指正式地）就某事情发表意见 · The play was pronounced ‘brilliant’ by all the critics. 所有评论家都认为这出戏“非常出色”。

pronounced
/prəˈnaʊnst ||; prəˈnaυnst/adj very noticeable; obvious 很明显的；显著的: His English is excellent although he speaks with a pronounced French accent. 他的英语虽然带着明显的法国口音，但说得好极了。

pronto
/prɒntəʊ ||; ˈprɑnto/adv (informal 非正式) quickly; immediately 立即；马上: Get back here, pronto! 马上回到这里！

*pronunciation
/prəˌnʌnsiˈeɪʃn ||; prəˌnʌnsɪˈeʃən/noun
1 [U] [C] the way in which a language or a particular word or sound is said 发音（法）；读法: American pronunciation 美国发音 ☞verb pronounce 动词为pronounce
2 [U] a person's way of speaking a language （某人的）发音（方式）: His grammar is good but his pronunciation is awful! 他语法掌握得不错，但发音很糟糕！

-proof
/prʌ:f;pru:f/ (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) able to protect against the thing mentioned 耐…的；防…的；抗…的: a soundproof room 隔音的房间 a waterproof/windproof jacket 防水╱防风夹克 bulletproof glass 防弹玻璃

*proof
/pru:f ||; pruf/noun
1 [U] proof (of sth);proof that... information, documents, etc which show that sth is true 证据；证明: ‘We need some proof of identity,’ the shop assistant said. “我们须要看看你的身分证明文件。”店员说。 You've got no proof that John took the money. 你没有证据证明约翰拿了那些钱。 ☞verb prove 动词为prove
2 [C] [usu.pl] (technical术语) a first copy of printed material that is produced so that mistakes can be corrected （印刷品的）校样

prop¹
/prɒp ||; prɑp/verb [T] (propping;propped) to support sb/sth or keep sb/sth in position by putting him/her/it against or on sth 支持；支撑；使保持在某个位置: I'll use this book to prop the window open. 我要用这本书撑开窗子。 He propped his bicycle against the wall. 他把自行车靠墙放。 prop sth up to support sth that would otherwise fall 支撑某物（使之不倒）
prop²
/prɒp ||; prɑp/noun[C]
1 a stick or other object that you use to support sth or to keep sth in position 支撑物；支柱: Rescuers used props to stop the roof of the tunnel collapsing. 救援人员使用支柱防止隧道顶部塌下来。
2 [usu.pl] an object that is used in a play, film, etc （戏剧、电影等用的）道具: He's responsible for all the stage props, machinery and lighting. 他负责所有的舞台道具、器械和灯光。

propaganda
/ˌprɒpəˈgændə ||; ˌprɑpəˈgændə/noun [U] information and ideas that may be false or exaggerated, which are used to gain support for a political leader, party, etc （为获取对政治领袖、政党等的支持而使用的）宣传: political propaganda 政治宣传

propagate
/ˈprɒpəgeɪt ||; ˈprɑpəˌget/verb [I,T] to produce new plants from a parent plant （植物）繁殖 ➔propagation /ˌprɒpəˈgeɪʃn ||; ˌprɑpəˈgeʃən/ noun [U]

propane
/ˈprəʊpeɪn ||; ˈpropen/noun [U] a colourless gas that is found in natural gas and petrol and that we use as a fuel for cooking and heating 丙烷

propel
/prəˈpel ||; prəˈpɛl/verb [T] (propelling;propelled) to move, drive or push sb/sth forward or in a particular direction 推进；推动

propeller
/prəˈpelə(r) ||; prəˈpɛlɚ/noun [C] a device with several flat metal parts(blades)which turn round very fast in order to make a ship or a plane move （船或飞机的）螺旋桨，推进器

propensity
/prəˈpensəti ||; prəˈpɛnsətɪ/noun [C] (plural propensities) (formal 正式)a propensity (for sth);a propensity (for doing sth);a propensity (to do sth) a habit of behaving in a particular way 习性；倾向: He showed a propensity for violence. 他表现出使用暴力的倾向。 She has a propensity to exaggerate. 她有把事情夸大的习性。

*proper
/ˈprɒpə(r) ||; ˈprɑpɚ/adj
1 (especially Brit 尤为英) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) right, suitable or correct 适宜的；合适的；正确的: If you're going skiing you must have the proper clothes. 如果你去滑雪，一定要穿上适当的衣服。 I've got to get these pieces of paper in the proper order. 我得把这几张纸按顺序排好。
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that you consider to be real or good enough 真实的；够好的: I didn't see much of the flat yesterday. I'm going to go today and have a proper look. 昨天我没有怎么看那公寓，今天我要去看个清楚。
3 (formal 正式) socially and morally acceptable 合乎社会和道德规范的；正规的；合乎体统的；得体的: I think it would be only proper for you to apologize. 我认为你应该道歉才是。 [OPP] improper 反义词为improper
4 (only after a noun 只用于名词后) real or main 真正；主要: We travelled through miles of suburbs before we got to the city proper. 我们在市郊走了好几英里路才到达市区。

properly
/ˈprɒpəli ||; ˈprɑpɚlɪ/adv
1 (especially Brit 尤为英) correctly; in an acceptable way 正确；以可以接受的方式；适当地: The teacher said I hadn't done my homework properly. 老师说我没有好好做家庭作业。 These shoes don't fit properly. 这双鞋子不合脚。
2 in a way that is socially and morally acceptable; politely 以合乎社会和道德规范的方式；有礼貌地: If you two children can't behave properly then we'll have to go home. 如果你们这两个孩子不守规矩，那末我们只得回家。 [OPP] improperly 反义词为improperly

ˌproper ˈname
(also ˌproper ˈnoun) noun [C] (grammar语法) a word which is the name of a particular person or place and begins with a CAPITAL LETTER 专有名词（以大写字母开头的人名或地名）: ‘Mary’ and ‘Rome’ are proper names. Mary和Rome都是专有名词。

*property
/ˈprɒpəti ||; ˈprɑpɚtɪ/noun (plural properties)
1 [U] a thing or things that belong to sb 所有物；财产；财物: The sack contained stolen property. 袋子里装着赃物。 Is this bag your property? 这袋子是你的东西吗？ This file is government property. 这档案是政府的财产。 ☞Look at lost property. 参看lost property。
2 [U] land and buildings 房地产: Property prices vary enormously from area to area. 房地产价格各地差异很大。
3 [C] one building and the land around it 建筑物及其四周的地方；房地产: There are a lot of empty properties in the area. 这地区有很多无人居住的房子。
4 [C] [usu.pl] (formal 正式) a special quality or characteristic that a substance, etc has （物质等的）特质，特性: Some plants have healing properties. 有些植物具有治疗功效。

prophecy
/ˈprɒfəsi ||; ˈprɑfəsɪ/noun [C] (plural prophecies) a statement about what is going to happen in the future 预言: to fulfil a prophecy (= to make it come true) 使预言应验

prophesy
/ˈprɒfəsaɪ ||; ˈprɑfəˌsaɪ/verb [T] (present participle prophesying third person singular present prophesies;past tense past participle prophesied) to say what you think will happen in the future 预言；预告未来: to prophesy disaster/war 预言有灾难发生╱将会爆发战争

prophet
/ˈprɒfɪt ||; ˈprɑfɪt/noun[C]
1 (also Prophet) (in the Christian, Jewish and Muslim religions) a person who is sent by God to teach the people and give them messages from God （基督教、犹太教及伊斯兰教的）先知
2 a person who says what will happen in the future 预言者；预言家 ➔prophetic /prəˈfetɪk ||; prəˈfɛtɪk/ adj

prophylactic¹
/ˌprɒfɪˈlæktɪk ||; ˌprɑfəˈlæktɪk/adj (medical医学) done or used in order to prevent a disease 预防（疾病）的: prophylactic treatment 预防性治疗
prophylactic²
/ˌprɒfɪˈlæktɪk ||; ˌprɑfəˈlæktɪk/noun [C] (formal 正式)or(technical术语) a medicine, device or course of action that prevents disease （疾病的）预防药，预防器，预防措施

*proportion
/prəˈpɔ:ʃn ||; prəˈpɔrʃən/noun
1 [C] a part or share of a whole 部份；份儿: A large proportion of the earth's surface is covered by sea. 地球表面大部份都由海洋覆盖。
2 [U] proportion (of sth to sth) the relationship between the size or amount of two things （两物在大小或数量上的）比，比例: The proportion of men to women in the college has changed dramatically over the years. 该学院的男女生比例这些年来变化很大。
3 proportions [pl] the size or shape of sth 大小；形状；规模: a room of odd proportions 形状古怪的房间 Political unrest is reaching alarming proportions. 政治动乱快达到令人忧虑的地步。
in proportion the right size in relation to other things 符合比例；相称: to draw sth in proportion 按实物的正确比例画出某物 She's so upset that it's hard for her to keep the problem in proportion (= to her it seems more important or serious than it really is). 她很懊恼，难以恰如其分地看待那问题（把问题看得比实际严重）。 in proportion to sth
1 by the same amount or number as sth else; relative to 与…成比例；与…相称: Salaries have not risen in proportion to inflation. 薪金没有按照通货膨胀率上调。
2 compared with 与…相比: In proportion to the number of students as a whole, there are very few women. 与学生总人数相比，女生只属极少数。
out of proportion (to sth)
1 too big, small, etc in relation to other things （因大小等与其他事物）不相称，不成比例
2 too great, serious, important, etc in relation to sth （与其他事物相比）显得过大、过分严重或过分重要等: His reaction was completely out of proportion to the situation. 他对情况的反应完全是小题大作。

proportional
/prəˈpɔ:ʃənl ||; prəˈpɔrʃənḷ/adj proportional (to sth) of the right size, amount or degree compared with sth else 成比例的；（大小、数量或程度上）相称的: Salary is proportional to years of experience. 薪金与资历是成比例的。 ➔proportionally adv

proˌportional ˌrepresenˈtation
noun [U] (abbr PR) a system that gives each political party in an election a number of representatives in parliament in direct relation to the number of votes its CANDIDATES (= people who want to be elected) receive 比例代表制（每个政党按其候选人在选举中所得票数的比例在议会中获得多少议席的选举制度） ☞Look at representation. 参看representation。

*proposal
/prəˈpəʊzl ||; prəˈpozḷ/noun[C]
1 a proposal (for/to do sth);a proposal that... a plan that is formally suggested 提案；建议；计划；方案: a new proposal for raising money 一个新的筹款计划 a proposal to build more student accommodation 一个建造更多学生宿舍的计划 May I make a proposal that we all give an equal amount? 容我提出一个建议，我们都给同样的数量，好不好？
2 an act of formally asking sb to marry you 求婚

*propose
/prəˈpəʊz ||; prəˈpoz/verb
1 [T] to formally suggest sth as a possible plan or action 提议；建议: At the meeting a new advertising campaign was proposed. 有人在会上建议开展一场新的宣传活动。
2 [T] to intend to do sth; to have sth as a plan 打算；计划: What do you propose to do now? 你现在打算怎么办？
3 [I,T] propose (to sb) to ask sb to marry you 向某人求婚 [T] to propose marriage 求婚
4 [T] propose sb for/as sth to suggest sb for an official position 提名，推荐（某人担任某职务）: I'd like to propose Anna Marsland as Chairperson. 我想提名安娜．马斯兰出任主席。

proposition
/ˌprɒpəˈzɪʃn ||; ˌprɑpəˈzɪʃən/noun[C]
1 an idea, a plan or an offer, especially in business; a suggestion 主张，计划，出价（尤指业务上的）；提议；建议: A month's holiday in Spain is an attractive proposition. 到西班牙度假一个月是个很有吸引力的提议。
2 an idea or opinion that sb expresses about sth （对某事物的）意见，看法，见解: That's a very interesting proposition. But can you prove it? 那是很有意思的见解，但你可加以证明吗？

proprietary
/prəˈpraɪətri; US -teri ||; prəˈpraɪəˌtɛrɪ/adj
1 (used about goods) made and sold by a particular company and protected by a registered trade name ﹙商品﹚专卖的，专利的，专营的: proprietary software 专营软件 proprietary brands 专利品牌
2 relating to an owner or to the fact of owning sth 所有人的；所有权的: The company has a proprietary right to the property. 公司拥有这笔财产的所有权。

proprietor
/prəˈpraɪətə(r) ||; prəˈpraɪətɚ/noun [C] (feminine proprietress /prəˈpraɪətres ||; prəˈpraɪətrɪs/) the owner of a business, a hotel, etc （公司、旅馆等的）老板，业主

prose
/prəʊz ||; proz/noun [U] written or spoken language that is not poetry 散文: to write in prose 以散文写作 ☞Compare poetry. 与poetry比较。

prosecute
/ˈprɒsɪkju:t ||; ˈprɑsɪˌkjut/verb [I,T] prosecute sb (for sth) to officially charge sb with a crime and try to show that he/she is guilty, in a court of law 检控；对…提起公诉 [I] the prosecuting counsel/lawyer/attorney 公诉律师；检察官 He was prosecuted for theft. 他被控盗窃。 ☞Look at defend. 参看defend。

prosecution
/ˌprɒsɪˈkju:ʃn ||; ˌprɑsɪˈkjuʃən/noun
1 [U] [C] the process of officially charging sb with a crime and of trying to show that he/she is guilty, in a court of law 检控；起诉: to bring a prosecution against sb 对某人提诉 Failure to pay your parking fine will result in prosecution. 不缴交违规停车罚款会被检控。
2 the prosecution [sing] [with.sop] a person or group of people who try to show that sb is guilty of a crime in a court of law 控方；原告: The prosecution claim/claims that Lloyd was driving at 100 miles per hour. 控方声称劳埃德当时以每小时100英里的车速驾驶。 ☞Look at defence. 参看defence。

prosecutor
/ˈprɒsɪkju:tə(r) ||; ˈprɑsɪˌkjutɚ/noun[C]
1 a public official who charges sb with a crime and tries to show that he/she is guilty in a court of law 公诉人；检察官: the public/state prosecutor 公诉人﹔国家检查官
2 a lawyer who leads the case against the accused person(the defendant)in a court of law 起诉人﹔主证人﹙被告叫做defendant﹚

prosody
/ˈprɒsədi ||; ˈprɑsədɪ/noun [U] (technical术语) the patterns of sounds and rhythms in poetry and speech; the study of this （诗及演说的）韵律，韵律学

prospect
/ˈprɒspekt ||; ˈprɑspɛkt/noun
1 [U] [sing] prospect (of sth/of doing sth) the possibility that sth will happen （某事发生的）可能性: There's little prospect of better weather before next week. 下星期之前天气好转的可能性不大。
2 [sing] prospect (of sth/of doing sth) a thought about what may or will happen in the future 期望；预期: The prospect of becoming a father filled James with horror. 詹姆斯快要为人之父，心里充满恐惧。
3 prospects [pl] chances of being successful in the future 前途；前景；展望: good job/career/promotion prospects 良好就业前景；良好事业前途；良好晋升机会

prospective
/prəˈspektɪv ||; prəˈspɛktɪv/adj likely to be or to happen; possible 可能出现的；即将发生的: prospective changes in the law 法律上可能出现的变化

prospectus
/prəˈspektəs ||; prəˈspɛktəs/noun [C] a small book which gives information about a school or college in order to advertise it 学校简介（宣传学校课程、设施等的小册子）

prosper
/ˈprɒspə(r) ||; ˈprɑspɚ/verb [I] to develop in a successful way; to be successful, especially with money 兴旺，繁荣，昌盛（尤指财富）

prosperity
/prɒˈsperəti ||; prɑsˈpɛrətɪ/noun [U] the state of being successful, especially with money 兴旺，繁荣，昌盛（尤指财富）: Tourism has brought prosperity to many parts of Spain. 旅游业使西班牙许多地区繁荣起来。

prosperous
/ˈprɒspərəs ||; ˈprɑspərəs/adj rich and successful 发达的；富饶的；兴旺的

prostate
/ˈprɒsteɪt ||; ˈprɑstet/ (also prostate gland) noun [C] a small organ in a man's body near the BLADDER(= the organ where waste liquid collects), that produces a liquid in which SPERM is carried 前列腺

prostitute
/ˈprɒstɪtju:t; US -tu:t ||; ˈprɑstəˌtut/noun [C] a person, especially a woman, who earns money by having sex with people 卖淫者；妓女

prostitution
/ˌprɒstɪˈtju:ʃn; US -ˈtu:ʃn ||; ˌprɑstəˈtuʃən/noun [U] working as a prostitute 卖淫；当娼

prostrate
/prɒˈstreɪt ||; ˈprɑstret/adj lying flat on the ground, facing downwards 俯伏在地的

protagonist
/prəˈtægənɪst ||; proˈtægənɪst/noun [C] (formal 正式) (in literature 文学) the main character in a play, film or book （戏剧、电影及书中的）主角，主人公

protease
/ˈprəʊtieɪz ||; ˈprotɪˌes/noun [U] (technical术语) an ENZYME that breaks down PROTEIN (= a natural substance found in meat, eggs, fish, etc that the body needs to grow and be healthy) 蛋白酶

*protect
/prəˈtekt ||; prəˈtɛkt/verb [T] protect sb/sth (against/from sth) to keep sb/sth safe; to defend sb/sth 保护；防御: Parents try to protect their children from danger as far as possible. 父母想尽量保护自己的子女免受危险。 Bats are a protected species (= they must not be killed). 蝙蝠是受保护的物种。

*protection
/prəˈtekʃn ||; prəˈtɛkʃən/noun [U] protection (against/from sth) the act of keeping sb/sth safe so that he/she/it is not harmed or damaged 保护；防御: Vaccination gives protection against diseases. 接种痲疹疫苗可预防痲疹。 After the attack he was put under police protection. 他遇袭后便受到警方的保护。

protectionism
/prəˈtekʃənɪzəm ||; prəˈtɛkʃənˌɪzəm/noun [U] (technical术语) the principle or practice of protecting a country's own industry by taxing foreign goods 保护（贸易）主义 ➔protectionist /-ʃənɪst ||; -ʃənɪst/ adj protectionist measures/policies 保护主义措施╱政策

protective
/prəˈtektɪv ||; prəˈtɛktɪv/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that prevents sb/sth from being damaged or harmed 保护的；防护的: In certain jobs workers need to wear protective clothing. 某些工作的工人需要穿着防护服。
2 protective (of/towards sb/sth) wanting to keep sb/sth safe 希望保护（某人或某物）；对（某人或某物）呵护备至: Female animals are very protective of their young. 雌性动物对幼崽呵护备至。

protector
/prəˈtektə(r) ||; prəˈtɛktɚ/noun [C] a person who protects sb/sth 保护者；防御者

protein
/ˈprəʊti:n ||; ˈprotin/noun [C,U] a substance found in food such as meat, fish, eggs and beans. It is important for helping people and animals to grow and be healthy. 蛋白质

*protest¹
/ˈprəʊtest ||; ˈprotɛst/noun [U] [C] protest (against sth) a statement or action that shows that you do not like or approve of sth 抗议书；抗议: He resigned in protest against the decision. 他为抗议那项决定而辞职。 The union organized a protest against the redundancies. 工会组织了抗议行动，反对裁员。 under protest not happily and after expressing disagreement 被逼；不情愿地: Fiona agreed to pay in the end but only under protest. 菲奥纳最后同意付款，但并不情愿。
*protest²
/prəˈtest ||; prəˈtɛst/verb
1 [I,T] protest (about/against/at sth) to say or show that you do not approve of or agree with sth, especially publicly 反对，抗议，抱怨（尤指公开地）: Students have been protesting against the government's decision. 学生们一直在抗议政府的决定。 In American English protest is used without a preposition They protested the government's handling of the situation. 在美国英语中，protest无须与介词连用：They protested the government's handling of the situation.他们反对政府处理局势的方式。
2 [T] to say sth firmly, especially when others do not believe you 坚决表示，断言，坚称（尤指在别人不相信时）: She has always protested her innocence. 她总是坚称自己无辜。 ☞ Protest is stronger and usually used about more serious things than complain. You protest about something that you feel is not right or fair, you complain about the quality of something or about a less serious action to protest about a new tax to complain about the poor weather. protest比complain语气更强，通常用于较严重的事情。就那些我们认为不对或不公平的事情提出抗议用protest，而投诉物品的质量差，或者抱怨不太严重的事情则用complain：to protest about a new tax 抗议新税 · to complain about the poor weather 抱怨天气不好。 ➔protester noun [C]: Protesters blocked the road outside the factory. 抗议者堵住工厂外面的道路。

*Protestant
/ˈprɒtɪstənt ||; ˈprɑtɪstənt/noun [C] a member of the Christian church that separated from the Catholic church in the 16th century 新教徒（指16世纪脱离天主教之基督教团体的成员） Protestant adj a Protestant church 新教教会 ☞Look at Roman Catholic. 参看Roman Catholic。

proto-
/ˈprəʊtəʊ ||; ˈprotə/prefix (used in nouns and adjectives 用于构成名词及形容词) original; from which others develop 原；母；初: prototype 原型

protocol
/ˈprəʊtəkɒl ||; ˈprotəˌkɔl/noun
1 [U] (formal 正式) a system of fixed rules and formal behaviour used at official meetings, usually between governments 外交礼仪（通常指政府间的）；礼节: a breach of protocol 外交礼仪的破坏 the protocol of diplomatic visits 外交访问的礼遇
2 [C] (technical术语) the first or original version of a written agreement, especially one between countries; an extra part added to a written agreement 议定书，协议书（尤指国家间的）；（协议书的）补充条款: the first Geneva Protocol 第一个日内瓦议定书 It is set out in a legally binding protocol which forms part of the treaty. 这在有法律效力的协议书中已经阐明，该协议书是条约的组成部份。
3 [C] (computing计算机技术) a set of rules that control the way information is sent between computers （计算机之间发送信息的）规程
4 [C] (technical术语) a plan for carrying out a scientific experiment or medical treatment 科学试验；治疗方案

proton
/ˈprəʊtɒn ||; ˈprotɑn/noun [C] one of the three types of PARTICLES that form all atoms. Protons have a positive electric charge. 质子 ☞Look at electron and neutron. 参看electron及neutron。

prototype
/ˈprəʊtətaɪp ||; ˈprotəˌtaɪp/noun [C] the first model or design of sth from which other forms will be developed 原型

protozoan
/ˌprəʊtəˈzəʊən ||; ˌprotəˈzoən/noun [C] (plural protozoans or protozoa /-ˈzəʊə ||; -ˈzoə/) a very small living thing, usually with only one cell, that can only be seen using a special piece of equipment that makes it look bigger(a microscope) 原生动物（一种很小的生物，在显微镜下才看得见，通常只有一个细胞）

protractor
/prəˈtræktə(r) ||; prəˈtræktɚ/noun [C] an instrument for measuring and drawing angles, usually made from a half circle of clear plastic with degrees (0° to 180° marked on it 量角器；分度规

protrude
/prəˈtru:d; US prəʊ- ||; proˈtrud/verb [I] protrude (from sth) to stick out from a place or surface （从某处或表面）伸出，突出: protruding eyes/teeth 鼓起的眼睛；凸出的牙齿

protrusion
/prəˈtru:ʒn ||; proˈtruʒən/noun [C,U] (formal 正式) a thing that sticks out from a place or surface; the fact of doing this 突出（物）；伸出（物）: a protrusion on the rock face 岩石表面的突出物

protuberance
/prəˈtju:bərəns ||; proˈtjubərəns/noun [C] (formal 正式) a round part that sticks out from a surface 圆形的隆起部份: The diseased trees have protuberances on their trunks. 病树的树干上有圆形的疙瘩。

*proud
/praʊd ||; praυd/adj
1 proud (of sb/sth);proud to do sth/that... feeling pleased and satisfied about sth that you own or have done 感到自豪的；感到得意的: They are very proud of their new house. 他们很满意自己的新房子。 I feel very proud to be part of such a successful organization. 身为这么成功的组织的一分子，我感到很光彩。 You should feel very proud that you have been chosen. 你给选中了，应该感到很自豪。
2 feeling that you are better and more important than other people 骄傲的；自大的；自负的: Now she's at university she'll be much too proud to talk to us! 她既已进了大学，必定自大得不屑与我们说话！
3 having respect for yourself and not wanting to lose the respect of others 有自尊的；自重的: He was too proud to ask for help. 他自尊心太强了，不会要求别人帮忙。 ☞noun pride 名词为pride ➔proudly adv ‘I did all the work myself,’ he said proudly. “我独力做了所有工作。”他得意地说。

*prove
/pru:v ||; pruv/verb (past participle proved (US 美) proven)
1 [T] prove sth (to sb) to use facts and evidence to show that sth is true 证明；证实: It will be difficult to prove that she was lying. 要证明她在说谎会很困难。 She tried to prove her innocence to the court. 她试图向法庭证明自己无罪。 He felt he needed to prove a point (= show other people that he was right). 他觉得自己有必要向别人证明自己是对的。 ☞noun proof 名词为proof
2 linking verb to show a particular quality over a period of time （一段时间内）显示某种特性，证明是，原来是: The job proved more difficult than we'd expected. 这份工作证明比我们预期的要难。
3 [T] prove yourself (to sb) to show other people how good you are at doing sth and/or that you are capable of doing sth 显示自己能干或有能力: He constantly feels that he has to prove himself to others. 他经常觉得自己非向别人露一手不可。

proven
/ˈprəʊvn; US ˈpru:vn ||; ˈpruvən/adj that has been shown to be true 已经证实的: a proven fact 已经验证的事实

proverb
/ˈprɒvɜ:b ||; ˈprɑvɝb/noun [C] a short well-known sentence or phrase that gives advice or says that sth is generally true in life 谚语；格言: ‘Too many cooks spoil the broth,’ is a proverb. “厨师多，烧坏汤”是句谚语。 ☞Look at saying. 参看saying。

proverbial
/prəˈvɜ:biəl ||; prəˈvɝbɪəl/adj
1 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) used to show you are referring to a well-known phrase(a proverb) 引用谚语的: Let's not count our proverbial chickens. 我们别数谚语里所讲的鸡吧。
2 well known and talked about by a lot of people 众所周知的

*provide
/prəˈvaɪd ||; prəˈvaɪd/verb [T] provide sb (with sth);provide sth (for sb) to give sth to sb or make sth available for sb to use; to supply sth 提供；供应: This book will provide you with all the information you need. 这本书能提供你需要的所有信息。 We are able to provide accommodation for two students. 我们能够为两名学生提供住宿。 ☞noun provision 名词为provision provide for sb to give sb all that he/she needs to live, for example food and clothing 供养；抚养: Robin has four children to provide for. 罗宾有四名子女要抚养。 provide for sth to make preparations to deal with sth that might happen in the future 为可能发生的事作安排或作准备；未雨绸缪: We did not provide for such a large increase in prices. 对这么大的涨幅我们没有做好准备。

*provided
/prəˈvaɪdɪd ||; prəˈvaɪdɪd/ (also providing) conj provided/providing (that) only if; on condition that 只要；假若: She agreed to go and work abroad provided (that) her family could go with her. 只要她的家人能跟她一起去，她同意到海外工作。

provider
/prəˈvaɪdə(r) ||; prəˈvaɪdɚ/noun [C] a person or an organization that supplies sb with sth he/she needs or wants 供应者；提供者；供养人: We are one of the largest providers of employment in the area. 我们是本地区最大的雇主之一。 The eldest son is the family's sole provider(= the only person in the family who earns money). 长子是这个家庭唯一养家糊口的人。 ☞ Look at ISP. 参看 ISP。

*province
/ˈprɒvɪns ||; ˈprɑvɪns/noun
1 [C] one of the areas that some countries are divided into with its own local government 省: Canada has ten provinces. 加拿大有十个省。 ☞Compare county and state. 与county及state比较。
2 the provinces [pl] (Brit 英) the part of a country that is outside the most important city(the capital) 首都以外的地方

provincial
/prəˈvɪnʃl ||; prəˈvɪnʃəl/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with one of the large areas that some countries are divided into 与省有关的: provincial governments/elections 省政府；省级选举
2 connected with the parts of a country that do not include its most important city 地方的: a provincial town/newspaper 地方的城镇；地方报
3 (used about a person or his/her ideas) not wanting to consider new or different ideas or fashions （指人或其思想）狭隘的，守旧的，不合潮流的: provincial attitudes 不合潮流的态度

*provision
/prəˈvɪʒn ||; prəˈvɪʒən/noun
1 [U] the giving or supplying of sth to sb or making sth available for sb to use 提供；供应: The council is responsible for the provision of education and social services. 地方议会负责提供教育及社会服务。
2 [U] provision for sb/sth preparations that you make to deal with sth that might happen in the future （为可能发生的事作的）预备，准备，安排: She made provision for (= planned for the financial future of) the children in the event of her death. 她为防备自己去世而为子女预作经济上的安排。
3 provisions [pl] (formal 正式) supplies of food and drink, especially for a long journey （尤指为长途旅行安排的）饮食供应 ☞verb provide 动词为provide

provisional
/prəˈvɪʒənl ||; prəˈvɪʒənḷ/adj only for the present time, that is likely to be changed in the future 临时的；暂时的: The provisional date for the next meeting is 18 November. 下次会议日期暂定11月18日。 a provisional driving licence(= that you use when you are learning to drive) 临时驾驶执照（学习驾驶时用的执照） ➔provisionally /-nəli ||; -nḷɪ/ adv I've only repaired the bike provisionally -- we'll have to do it properly later. 我只是将自行车暂时修了修，我们以后还得把它好好修一下。

proviso
/prəˈvaɪzəʊ ||; prəˈvaɪzo/noun [C] (plural provisos) a condition that must be accepted before an agreement can be made （达成协议前必须接受的）条件: He agreed to the visit with the proviso that they should stay no longer than a week. 他同意来访，条件是他们逗留的时间不得超过一个星期。

provocation
/ˌprɒvəˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌprɑvəˈkeʃən/noun [U] [C] doing or saying sth deliberately to try to make sb angry or upset; sth that is said or done to cause this 挑衅；触怒: You should never hit children, even under extreme provocation. 就算有什么事惹得你极为恼火，也绝不该打孩子。 ☞verb provoke 动词为provoke

provocative
/prəˈvɒkətɪv ||; prəˈvɑkətɪv/adj
1 intended to make sb angry or upset or to cause an argument 蓄意引起争执的；挑衅的: He made a provocative remark about a woman's place being in the home. 他说了一句挑衅的话，说什么女人应该待在家中。
2 intended to cause sexual excitement 挑逗的；撩人的 ➔provocatively adv

provoke
/prəˈvəʊk ||; prəˈvok/verb[T]
1 to cause a particular feeling or reaction 激起，引起（感觉或反应）: an article intended to provoke discussion 一篇旨在引起讨论的文章
